Name: 3/4 Sit-up
Description:
1. Start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. You can place your hands either on your chest, crossed over your stomach, or behind your head (without pulling on the neck).

2. Engage your core muscles by pulling your belly button towards your spine, keeping your lower back pressed against the floor or mat.

3. Slowly lift your upper body off the ground, curling your torso towards your thighs. Remember to keep your lower back on the floor to avoid straining it. It should feel like you are peeling your upper spine off the ground.

4. Continue the movement until your shoulder blades are a few inches off the ground. This is the 3/4 point of the sit-up, hence the exercise name.

5. Hold this position for a few seconds while squeezing your abdominal muscles.

6. Lower your upper body back down to the starting position in a controlled manner, keeping your core engaged.

Name: Air bike
Description:
1. Start by lying flat on your back on a mat or an exercise surface.

2. Place your hands gently behind your head, allowing your elbows to be slightly bent.

3. Lift your legs off the ground and bend your knees at a 90-degree angle, so your lower legs are parallel to the floor.

4. Simultaneously, lift your head, neck, and shoulders off the ground. Keep your core engaged throughout the exercise.

5. Begin the movement by straightening your left leg while simultaneously rotating your upper body to the left so that your right elbow meets your left knee.

6. As you complete the first movement, switch sides by bending your left knee and straightening your right leg while simultaneously rotating your upper body to the right so that your left elbow meets your right knee. This creates a cycling motion.

7. Continue alternating sides in a controlled and fluid manner, while maintaining proper form and engaging your abdominal muscles.

Note: It is crucial to maintain proper form and avoid excessive pulling on the neck during this exercise. If you're new to this movement, focus on executing it correctly rather than speed or volume.

Name: Barbell Bench Front Squat
Description:
1. Set up a barbell on a squat rack at chest height and load it with an appropriate weight.

2. Stand facing away from the barbell and position yourself in a shoulder-width stance.

3. Bend your knees and lower your body into a squat position, grabbing the barbell with an overhand grip just outside shoulder width.

4. Lift the barbell off the rack and walk a few steps forward, ensuring your feet are shoulder-width apart and your toes are pointing slightly outward.

5. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and hips, keeping your back straight and chest up. Continue descending until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower.

6. Pause for a moment at the bottom of the squat and then push through your heels to rise back up to the starting position.

7. Once you are fully standing, carefully walk backward to return the barbell to the squat rack.

8. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Barbell Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by lying flat on a weight bench, feet firmly planted on the ground and positioned at a shoulder-width distance apart.

2. Grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Lift the barbell off the rack or have a spotter assist you in doing so.

3. Lower the barbell slowly towards your chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Lower the bar until it touches your chest lightly or until your upper arms are parallel to the floor.

4. Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement, then push the barbell back up, extending your arms fully without locking your elbows. Aim to keep your wrists straight and your core engaged throughout the movement.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring controlled and smooth movements. Once done, either have a spotter assist you in reracking the barbell or carefully do so yourself.

Name: Barbell Bench Squat
Description:
1. Set up a barbell on a squat rack at an appropriate height. Make sure the weight on the barbell is suitable for your training goals and capabilities.

2. Place a bench directly behind the squat rack, positioning it at a distance that allows you to comfortably sit down and stand up while keeping your feet grounded.

3. Position yourself under the barbell, ensuring that it rests across your upper back and shoulders. Grip the barbell with your hands at a distance that feels stable and comfortable.

4. Step out of the racked position and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outward. Take a deep breath, brace your core, and prepare to initiate the squat.

5. Lower yourself down towards the bench by bending your hips and knees, simulating a regular squatting motion. Try to maintain a neutral spine angle and keep your knees tracking in line with your toes.

6. Once your glutes touch the bench, pause briefly, maintaining tension in your legs and core. Avoid fully sitting down or relaxing on the bench.

7. Push through your feet and drive back up to the starting position, extending your knees and hips to stand tall. Remember to breathe out during this upward phase of the movement.

8. Repeat the squatting motion for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring proper form and control throughout the exercise.

9. After completing the set, carefully rack the barbell back on the squat rack, ensuring it is secure and stable.

Name: Barbell Bent Over Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Middle Fibers, Trapezius Upper Fibers
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip, positioning your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips, maintaining a straight back and keeping your core engaged. Your torso should be almost parallel to the floor, approximately at a 45-degree angle.

3. With your arms fully extended and perpendicular to the floor, lift the barbell towards your upper abdomen by pulling your elbows back. The movement should be initiated by squeezing your shoulder blades together.

4. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement when the barbell touches your abdomen, and then slowly lower the weight back to the starting position, maintaining control and avoiding any jerking or swinging motions.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring proper form and maintaining a stable lower back throughout the movement.

The barbell bent over row primarily targets the muscles of the upper back, including the rhomboids, trapezius, and latissimus dorsi. It also engages the biceps, rear deltoids, and core muscles as stabilizers.

Name: Barbell Close-Grip Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Begin by setting up a barbell on a weight rack at a comfortable height. Position yourself on a workout bench, lying flat on your back.

2. Grab the barbell with a close grip, placing your hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width apart. Make sure your palms are facing forward, and your elbows are pointing down and tucked in towards your body.

3. Lower the barbell slowly and controlled towards your lower chest, while keeping your elbows close to your body throughout the movement. Aim to touch your chest lightly with the barbell.

4. Push the barbell back up to the starting position by extending your arms, but avoid fully locking out your elbows at the top. Maintain tension in your chest and triceps.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring your form remains correct and your breathing is controlled.

Name: Barbell Curl
Description:
1. Start by standing straight with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with an underhand grip (palms facing upward) at shoulder-width distance.

2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and slowly curl the barbell upwards, ensuring that only your forearms are moving. Exhale as you lift.

3. Continue curling until the barbell reaches shoulder level and you feel a contraction in your biceps. Hold the position for a brief moment to maximize the muscle engagement.

4. Slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position while inhaling. Make sure to maintain control and avoid using your momentum to swing the weight.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions. Adjust the resistance(weight) according to your fitness level and goals.

Name: Barbell Deadlift
Synergist: Adductor Magnus, Erector Spinae, Hamstrings, Quadriceps, Soleus
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet hip-width apart and a loaded barbell on the floor in front of you. The barbell should be close to your shins.

2. With your arms extended and hands gripping the barbell just outside your legs, lower your hips and bend your knees, maintaining a neutral spine and a slight arch in your lower back.

3. Engage your core, push through your heels, and lift the barbell off the ground using your legs and glutes, extending your hips and knees until you are standing tall.

4. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, ensuring that your shoulders are pulled back, and your torso is upright. Bring your scapulas together.

5. Lower the barbell back to the ground by hinging at your hips, pushing your hips back, and bending your knees, while keeping your back straight and core engaged.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps, ensuring proper form throughout the movement.

Name: Barbell Decline Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by setting up a decline bench at a 30 to 45-degree angle. Secure your feet firmly on the foot pads provided to maintain stability during the exercise.

2. Position yourself on the bench with your head lower than your hips. Lie down on the bench and grab the barbell with an overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Your palms should face forward.

3. Lift the barbell off the rack and slowly lower it towards your lower chest, keeping your elbows tucked in close to your sides. Your upper arms should create a 45-degree angle with your torso.

4. As you lower the bar down, inhale and pause briefly when the barbell is just above your chest.

5. Push the barbell back up using your chest muscles, driving your elbows upwards. Exhale as you press the weight overhead.

6. Continue pressing the barbell up until your arms are fully extended, but avoid locking out your elbows.

7. Hold the bar at the top for a moment, squeezing your chest muscles, before slowly lowering the weight back down to the starting position.

8. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining control and proper form throughout the exercise.

Note: It is crucial to start with an appropriate weight that allows you to perform the exercise with correct form. If you are new to this exercise, it is advisable to have a spotter present for safety and assistance.

Name: Barbell Decline Bent Arm Pullover
Synergist: Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. The Barbell Decline Bent Arm Pullover is an exercise primarily targeting the muscles of the chest, back, and arms. Here are the steps to perform this exercise:

2. Position yourself on a decline bench, ensuring that your head is below your hips. Lie down and place your feet securely on the foot support or have a partner hold your legs to stabilize you.

3. Hold a barbell with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. Your arms should be bent at approximately 90 degrees, with the barbell positioned directly above your chest.

4. Lower the barbell slowly and with control behind your head, until your upper arms are parallel to the floor. This movement requires bending your elbows while keeping them slightly fixed during the exercise.

5. Once you have reached the maximum stretch point, exhale and reverse the movement, pulling the barbell back to the starting position above your chest. Keep your core engaged and maintain control throughout the entire range of motion.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, making sure to focus on the contraction and extension of the chest and back muscles.

Note: It is important to use an appropriate weight that challenges your muscles without compromising your form. Start with lighter weights to master the technique before gradually increasing the load. Additionally, if you have any pre-existing shoulder, back, or neck issues, or if you feel any pain or discomfort during the exercise, it is advisable to consult with a fitness professional.

Name: Barbell Decline Close Grip To Skull Press
Description:
1. Begin by positioning yourself on a decline bench with your feet securely placed on the foot pads and the back of the bench angled downwards.

2. Grasp a barbell with a close grip, hands shoulder-width apart, and ensure that your palms are facing towards your feet.

3. Start with the barbell at your chest level, with your elbows pointing slightly forward and your upper arms perpendicular to the floor.

4. Inhale deeply, and then slowly lower the barbell towards your forehead by flexing your elbows, keeping them close to your head throughout the movement. The barbell should be lowered until it is just above your forehead.

5. Exhale as you extend your arms back up to the starting position, pushing the barbell back up while keeping your elbows locked and maintaining control of the weight.

6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, making sure to maintain proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Important Tip: It is crucial to use an appropriate weight and gradually increase it as you become more comfortable with the movement. It is also advisable to perform this exercise under the guidance of a qualified fitness professional to ensure correct technique and safety.

Name: Barbell Decline Wide-grip Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by lying on a decline bench, with your feet secured at the top end of the bench and your head positioned at the lower end.

2. Grasp a barbell with a wide grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Your palms should be facing away from you.

3. Extend your arms fully and position the barbell above your chest, making sure to keep the bar in a straight line with your shoulders.

4. Slowly lower the barbell towards your chest, while maintaining control and keeping your elbows out to the sides. Aim to lower the barbell until it lightly touches your lower chest.

5. Push the barbell back up to the starting position by extending your arms, while keeping tension in your chest muscles. Avoid locking your elbows at the top of the movement to ensure constant tension on the muscles.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement.

Note: This exercise specifically targets the lower chest muscles and using a wide grip adds emphasis to the outer portion of the chest. It is important to start with a weight that you can handle safely and gradually increase the resistance as your strength improves.

Name: Barbell Decline wide-grip pullover
Synergist: Deltoid Posterior, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Teres Major, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. The Barbell Decline wide-grip pullover is an exercise that targets the muscles of the chest, back, and triceps. Here are the steps to perform this exercise:

2. Start by adjusting a decline bench to approximately a 30-45 degree angle. Lie down on the bench, ensuring that your feet are firmly positioned and that your head is at the lower end of the bench.

3. Grab a barbell with a wide grip using both hands, palms facing away from you. Position the barbell above your chest, with your arms extended and elbows slightly bent.

4. Inhale and slowly lower the barbell towards the back of your head, keeping your arms extended and maintaining control throughout the movement. This is your starting position.

5. Exhale and engage your chest muscles as you raise the barbell back to the starting position, directly above your chest. Keep your arms extended and avoid using momentum to lift the weight.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring that you maintain proper form and control throughout the exercise.

7. Once you have completed the desired number of repetitions, carefully rack the barbell and return to a seated position on the bench.

It is essential to use proper form and start with a weight that you can manage comfortably. Consult with a fitness professional if you are unsure about the appropriate weight or have any concerns about performing this exercise.

Name: Barbell Drag Curl
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Anterior, Deltoid Posterior
Description:
1. Begin by standing tall with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Hold a barbell with an underhand grip, palms facing up, and hands shoulder-width apart.

2. Position the barbell close to your body, resting it against your thighs. Keep your back straight and engage your core muscles for stability throughout the exercise.

3. Slowly lift the barbell by flexing your elbows, moving them backward behind your body. As you do this, focus on contracting your biceps and keeping your upper arms stationary against your sides.

4. Continue lifting the barbell until your forearms are in an almost vertical position, making sure to maintain the same grip and keep your wrists straight.

5. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, squeezing your biceps before slowly lowering the barbell back down to the starting position, following the same path.

6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, making sure to execute the exercise with controlled and deliberate movements.

Name: Barbell Front Chest Squat
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell in front of your chest with an overhand grip. Your elbows should be pointing forward and slightly raised.

2. Engage your core and keep your back straight as you bend your knees and lower your body into a squatting position. Ensure that your knees are tracking over your toes and your weight is evenly distributed on both feet.

3. As you descend, keep the barbell close to your chest and maintain an upright position. It may help to imagine sitting back into a chair to maintain proper form.

4. Once you reach a comfortable depth, pause briefly, and then push through your heels to return to the starting position, fully extending your legs and squeezing your glutes.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, keeping your core engaged and maintaining control throughout the exercise.
Note: The barbell front chest squat is a challenging variation of the traditional squat, placing more emphasis on the muscles in your chest, shoulders, and core. It is recommended to start with lighter weights and gradually increase as you become comfortable with the technique.

Name: Barbell Front Raise and Pullover
Target: Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Deltoid Lateral, Latissimus Dorsi, Serratus Anterior, Teres Major, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by lying flat on a bench with your feet firmly planted on the ground and gripping a barbell with an overhand grip. Ensure your hands are slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Hold the barbell with your arms extended towards the ceiling, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. This is the starting position.

3. Begin the movement by lowering the barbell towards your chest, engaging your lats and triceps. Keep your elbows slightly bent throughout the exercise to avoid strain on the joints.

4. Once the barbell reaches just above your chest, reverse the movement by lifting the barbell back up towards the starting position, focusing on engaging your chest muscles.

5. As the barbell reaches the top position, simultaneously raise your arms in front of you until they are parallel to the ground. This engages your shoulders and targets the anterior deltoids.

6. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the barbell back down towards your chest, following the same path you initially used to raise it.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions. It is important to maintain control and focus on proper form throughout the exercise to maximize its benefits and minimize the risk of injury.

Name: Barbell Front Raise
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior
Description:
1. The Barbell Front Raise is an upper body exercise that primarily targets the front deltoids (shoulder muscles). Here are the steps to perform this exercise:

2. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, grasping a barbell with an overhand grip. Your palms should be facing down, and your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Hold the barbell in front of your thighs with your arms fully extended and your elbows slightly bent.

4. Keeping your back straight and core engaged, exhale and slowly lift the barbell directly in front of you, until it reaches shoulder height. Make sure to keep your arms straight throughout the movement, with a slight bend in the elbows.

5. Hold the lifted position for a brief moment while squeezing your shoulder muscles to maximize the contraction.

6. Inhale and slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position, controlling the movement and keeping it under your control.


It's important to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, keeping your body stable and minimizing any swinging or jerking movements. Additionally, you can adjust the weight on the barbell to suit your strength and fitness level.

Name: Barbell Front Squat
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and position a barbell across the front of your shoulders. Ensure your grip is shoulder-width apart and your elbows are pointing forward.

2. Engage your core and maintain an upright posture as you lower your body into a squatting position. Bend your knees and hips, and push your hips back as if sitting into an imaginary chair.

3. As you lower yourself down, keep your chest up and your back straight. Aim to get your thighs parallel to the ground or lower, if possible, while maintaining proper form.

4. Push through your heels and extend your knees and hips as you return to the starting position. Keep your core engaged throughout the movement to stabilize your body.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring that you maintain proper form and control throughout.

Name: Barbell Full Squat
Description:
1. Start by setting up a barbell at an appropriate weight for your fitness level and strength. The barbell should be placed on a squat rack or a power rack at about shoulder height.

2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, positioning yourself underneath the barbell. Your feet should be slightly turned outwards, and the barbell should rest on your upper back, just below your neck. Grip the barbell with both hands, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Take a deep breath and engage your core muscles. Begin the movement by bending at your hips and knees, pushing your hips back and down as if you were sitting back into a chair. Make sure to keep your chest up, back straight, and your gaze forward throughout the movement.

4. Continue descending until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. Your knees should be in line with your toes, and your weight evenly distributed through your feet.

5. From the bottom position, push through your heels and extend your hips and knees simultaneously to return to the starting position. Exhale as you rise, and make sure to maintain control and stability throughout the movement.

6. Repeat the squat for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and technique. Remember to always start with a weight that you can comfortably lift and progress gradually over time as your strength and proficiency improve.

Name: Barbell Good Morning
Description:
1. Start by placing a loaded barbell on the rack just below shoulder height. Step under the bar so it rests across your upper back and traps.

2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart and slight bend the knees. Keep your back straight and engage your core.

3. Unlock your hips and begin to hinge forward from the hips, pushing your buttocks back. Keep your back straight and your head in a neutral position.

4. Continue to lower your torso until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Try to maintain a straight back and avoid rounding or arching.

5. Once you reach the maximum stretch, reverse the movement and drive through your hips to return to the starting position. Squeeze your glutes at the top as you stand back up.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions while maintaining proper form and control throughout.

Name: Barbell Incline Bench Press
Description:
1. Start by lying on an incline bench with your feet flat on the ground and the barbell racked or held above your upper chest. Your palms should be facing forward and hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Begin the movement by unracking the barbell and lowering it slowly towards your upper chest while inhaling. Ensure that your elbows are slightly tucked in and your upper arms are at a 45-degree angle to your torso.

3. Once the barbell lightly touches your upper chest, push it back up by extending your arms and exhaling. Focus on using your chest muscles to drive the movement and avoid arching your back excessively.

4. Keep a controlled and smooth tempo throughout the exercise, avoiding any sudden jerking or bouncing of the weight.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions. Once you complete the set, carefully rack the barbell back or hand it off to a spotter if needed.

Name: Barbell Incline Reverse-grip Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head
Description:
1. Position yourself on an incline bench with your feet firmly planted on the ground.

2. Grasp the barbell with a reverse grip, which means your palms should be facing towards your face and your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder width apart.

3. Lift the barbell off the rack and hold it directly above your chest with your arms extended. This will be your starting position.

4. Slowly lower the barbell towards your upper chest, maintaining control and keeping your elbows slightly tucked in.

5. Pause for a second at the bottom of the movement, then push the barbell back up to the starting position by extending your arms and squeezing your chest muscles.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Barbell Incline Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Minor , Tibialis Anterior, Trapezius Middle Fibers, Trapezius Upper Fibers
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Set up an incline bench at approximately a 45-degree angle. Position it with the barbell rack close to the bottom of the bench.

2. Grab the barbell with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, and place it on the rack.

3. Position yourself by lying face down on the bench. Your shoulders should be at the top of the incline, with the barbell hanging just below the bench, arms fully extended.

4. Engage your core and maintain a neutral spine position throughout the exercise.

5. Begin the movement by retracting your shoulder blades and pulling the barbell towards your chest, slightly higher than your ribcage. Keep your elbows close to your body as you lift.

6. Pause for a brief moment at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

7. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

8. Once you have completed the set, carefully place the barbell back on the rack and slowly sit up from the incline bench.

Name: Barbell Lunge
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a barbell across the back of your shoulders, resting on your traps.

2. Take a step forward with one foot, ensuring that your core is engaged and your back remains straight.

3. Lower your body by bending both knees, until your front thigh is parallel to the ground and your back knee is hovering just above the floor.

4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position, and then repeat the movement with the opposite leg, alternating between sides.

Note: It's important to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, keeping your chest up, shoulders back, and knees tracking over your toes. Start with lighter weights to ensure correct technique before progressing to heavier loads.

Name: Barbell Lying Close-grip Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Begin by lying on a flat bench with your feet planted firmly on the floor. Place your hands on the barbell using a close-grip, slightly narrower than shoulder-width apart.

2. Lift the barbell off the rack and hold it above your chest with your arms fully extended. This is your starting position.

3. Lower the barbell slowly towards the middle of your chest, keeping your elbows tucked close to your sides.

4. Once the barbell touches your chest, pause for a moment, and then push the barbell back up to the starting position by extending your arms.

Name: Barbell Lying Close-grip Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Start by lying flat on a bench, holding a barbell with an overhand grip and your hands close together, about shoulder-width apart.

2. Extend your arms straight up towards the ceiling, keeping your elbows locked and close to your head throughout the exercise.

3. Slowly lower the barbell towards your forehead, bending your elbows to lower it as far as you can while maintaining control and keeping your upper arms stationary.

4. Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement, then use your triceps to press the barbell back up to the starting position.

5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring that you maintain proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Barbell Lying extension
Description:
1. Begin by lying with your back on a flat bench, feet planted firmly on the ground and knees bent at a 90-degree angle.

2. Grab a barbell with a shoulder-width grip, with your palms facing up and your hands slightly wider than your shoulders.

3. Keep your arms extended and perpendicular to the ground, holding the barbell directly above your chest.

4. In a slow and controlled motion, lower the barbell towards your forehead by bending your elbows. Keep your upper arms stationary, only allowing your forearms to move.

5. Pause for a moment at the bottom of the movement, feeling a stretch in your triceps.

6. Engage your triceps to push the barbell back to the starting position, fully extending your elbows.

7. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Barbell Lying Lifting (on hip)
Description:
1. Start by lying flat on your back on a weight bench with your legs extended and feet flat on the ground. Your knees should be bent at a 90-degree angle.

2. Grab a barbell with an overhand grip, placing your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Your palms should be facing up towards the ceiling.

3. Lift the barbell off the floor, bending your elbows and bringing it towards your hips. Your upper arms should remain parallel to the floor throughout the exercise.

4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position, slowly and controlled, until your elbows are fully extended and the barbell is hovering just above the floor.

5. Repeat the lifting motion for the desired number of repetitions, keeping your core engaged and maintaining proper form throughout the exercise.

6. Once you have completed the set, carefully place the barbell back on the floor and rest before proceeding with additional sets or exercises.

Name: Barbell One Leg Squat
Description:
1. The exercise 'Barbell One Leg Squat' is also known as the Pistol Squat. Here are the steps to perform this exercise:

2. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell across your upper back, resting it on your trapezius muscles.

3. Lift one foot off the ground and extend your leg forward, keeping it straight throughout the movement. This will be your working leg.

4. Slowly lower your body by bending your standing leg at the knee, as if you are sitting back into a chair. Keep your back straight and your core engaged for stability.

5. Descend until your working leg is parallel to the ground or as low as you can comfortably go, while maintaining good form. You can extend your arms in front of you to counterbalance your body.

6. Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement, then engage your quadriceps and glute muscles to push through the heel of your standing foot and return to the starting position.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, then switch legs.

Tips:
- It is important to maintain a slow and controlled movement to ensure proper form and maximize muscle engagement.
- If you're finding it difficult to perform the exercise with a barbell, you can start by using only your body weight or hold onto a TRX strap or any stable support for balance.
- Don't forget to warm up your legs and hips before attempting this exercise, as it requires good lower body strength and mobility.

Name: Barbell Preacher Curl
Description:
1. Start by setting up a preacher curl bench, which is a specially-designed bench with an angled pad for your upper arms to rest on. Ensure that it is set at a height that allows your arms to fully extend without any strain.

2. Grab a barbell with an underhand grip (palms facing up) and stand behind the preacher curl bench. Position your upper arms on the angled pad and rest your chest against the top cushion, keeping your feet shoulder-width apart.

3. Lower the barbell slowly, allowing your arms to fully extend. Ensure that your elbows remain on the pad at all times.

4. Engage your biceps and curl the barbell upwards while exhaling, contracting your biceps fully. Keep your upper arms stationary throughout the movement and focus on using your biceps to lift the weight.

5. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, squeezing your biceps, before slowly lowering the barbell back down to the starting position while inhaling.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring a controlled and smooth movement throughout the entire range of motion.

Note: It is important to start with an appropriate weight that allows you to maintain proper form and technique. If you are new to this exercise, consider working with a trainer or starting with a lighter weight to avoid injury.

Name: Barbell Rear Delt Row
Synergist: Brachialis, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. The Barbell Rear Delt Row is an exercise that targets the muscles in the back of your shoulder known as the rear deltoids. Here are the steps to perform this exercise:

2. Start by standing up straight with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Hold a barbell with an overhand grip and let it rest against your thighs.

3. Bend your knees slightly and lean forward from your hips, maintaining a neutral spine. Your torso should be angled roughly 45 degrees to the floor.

4. Engage your core and retract your shoulder blades. This will be your starting position.

5. Begin the movement by pulling the barbell up towards your upper abdomen, keeping your elbows close to your body. Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together as you lift the weight.

6. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, feeling the contraction in your rear delts.

7. Slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the descent.

8. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Tips:
- Make sure to maintain proper form throughout the exercise. Avoid rounding your back or hunching your shoulders.
- Keep your elbows close to your body to engage the rear delts effectively.
- Always start with a weight that is appropriate for your fitness level and gradually increase the weight as you become stronger.
- Focus on the mind-muscle connection to ensure you are targeting your rear deltoids effectively.

Name: Barbell Rear Lunge
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with your feet hip-width apart and hold the barbell with an overhand grip, resting at shoulder level across the back of your shoulders.

2. Take a step backward with one leg, keeping your torso straight and core engaged. Lower your body down by bending both knees until your back knee is a few inches off the ground and your front thigh is parallel to the floor.

3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position, bringing your back foot back to meet the front foot.

4. Repeat the lunge on the other leg, taking a step backward and lowering down into the lunge position. Continue alternating legs until you have completed the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Barbell Revers Wrist Curl (version 2)
Description:
1. Start by positioning yourself behind a flat bench with a barbell placed on the floor in front of you.

2. Sit on the bench and position your feet flat on the floor, shoulder-width apart.

3. Reach forward and grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

4. Rest your forearms on the bench with your wrists hanging off the edge, allowing the barbell to rest on the top of your hands.

5. Slowly curl your wrists upward, lifting the barbell while keeping your forearms stationary and in contact with the bench. Exhale as you perform this movement.

6. Contract your wrist muscles at the top of the movement and hold the position briefly.

7. Lower the barbell back down to the starting position in a controlled manner, allowing your wrists to flex back and the barbell to rest on the top of your hands.

8. Repeat the movement for the prescribed number of repetitions.

9. To increase the challenge, you can add weight to the barbell as you become stronger.

Name: Barbell Reverse Curl
Description:
1. Begin by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart, and grasp a barbell with an overhand grip (hands should be slightly wider than shoulder-width apart).

2. With your upper arms stationary by your sides, exhale and slowly curl the barbell upwards towards your shoulders, making sure to keep your elbows and upper arms locked in place.

3. Continue curling until your biceps are fully contracted and the barbell is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a brief second while squeezing your biceps.

4. Inhale and slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position, keeping control of the weight and ensuring your elbows remain stationary.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps.

Name: Barbell Reverse Preacher Curl
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a preacher bench, which is a fixed, angled bench with a pad to support your upper arms. Adjust the height of the seat so that your armpits rest comfortably on top of the pad, and your feet are firmly planted on the ground.

2. Grasp a barbell with an underhand grip (palms facing down) that is slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Your hands should be positioned shoulder-width apart on the bar, and your arms should be fully extended and straight down in front of you.

3. Keep your upper arms flat against the pad throughout the movement and maintain a slight bend in your elbows. This is your starting position.

4. Slowly curl the barbell upwards by contracting your biceps, while keeping your upper arms stationary against the pad. Focus on squeezing your biceps as you lift the weight.

5. Continue the upward movement until your forearms are fully contracted and the barbell is close to your shoulders.

6. Pause for a brief moment at the top, feeling the squeeze in your biceps, and then slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position with control. Avoid allowing the weight to drop or using momentum to lift the barbell.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, usually 8-

8. Make sure to maintain proper form throughout the movement, keeping your back straight, core engaged, and avoiding any excessive swinging or using your shoulders to lift the weight.

Name: Barbell Reverse Wrist Curl
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a barbell with an overhand grip, palms facing downward. The barbell should be at arm's length, resting on your thighs.

2. Keeping your arms stationary, exhale and slowly curl your wrists backward, lifting the barbell towards your forearms. Make sure to keep your forearms and elbows pressed against your body as you perform the movement.

3. Hold the top position for a brief pause and squeeze your forearms, then inhale and slowly return to the starting position by uncurling your wrists and lowering the barbell back down to your thighs.

4. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement.

Name: Barbell Romanian Deadlift
Description:
1. The Barbell Romanian Deadlift is a compound exercise that primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes. Here are the steps to perform this exercise:

2. Starting Position: Stand behind a barbell with your feet hip-width apart. The barbell should be resting on the floor in front of you with your hands shoulder-width apart. Maintain a slight bend in your knees and keep your back straight.

3. Hinge at the Hips: Begin the movement by hinging at the hips and bending forward, pushing your buttocks back while keeping your chest up. As you lower your torso, allow the barbell to slide down your thighs, maintaining a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

4. Lower the Barbell: Continue lowering the barbell until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, but avoid rounding your back or allowing your knees to excessively bend. You should keep your shin bones relatively vertical.

5. Push Through the Heels: Once you've reached the bottom position, push through your heels while engaging your hamstrings and glutes to raise your torso back up. Focus on squeezing your glutes at the top of the movement.

6. Repeat: Perform the desired number of repetitions while maintaining proper form. It's important to keep the movement controlled and not rely on momentum or jerk motions.

Remember to start with a weight that allows you to maintain proper form and gradually increase the load as you progress. It's also important to consult a professional or trainer if you're unsure about your technique or have any pre-existing conditions or injuries.

Name: Barbell Seated Behind Head Military Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a flat bench with a barbell placed on a rack at shoulder height behind your head. Adjust the bench so that your feet are firmly planted on the ground, and your back is supported against the bench.

2. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, with palms facing forward. Your wrists should be straight, and elbows pointed outwards.

3. Lift the barbell off the rack and bring it down in front of your head, resting it just above your upper chest, with your elbows bent.

4. Exhale and press the barbell overhead by extending your arms straight up. Keep your back straight, and avoid arching or leaning backward. This is your starting position.

5. Once the barbell reaches the top position, hold it briefly, and then slowly lower it back down to the starting position by bending your elbows and bringing it carefully back down behind your head.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, focusing on proper form and control throughout the exercise.

7. Once you have completed your set, carefully rack the barbell back on the rack, making sure it is secure, and then stand up from the bench.

Name: Barbell Seated Calf Raise
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on a bench or seat with your feet flat on the floor, about hip-width apart, and your knees bent at a 90-degree angle. Place a barbell across your thighs, holding it securely with an overhand grip.

2. Keeping your upper body stationary, lift your heels off the ground by extending your ankles as much as possible. This is your starting position.

3. Slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position, feeling a stretch in your calf muscles. Pause for a moment at the bottom before repeating the movement for the desired number of reps.

4. To increase the intensity, you can gradually add weight to the barbell or try using one leg at a time instead of both to target each calf separately.

Name: Barbell Seated Close-grip Concentration Curl
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a bench with your feet flat on the floor and your knees bent at a 90-degree angle. Hold a barbell with an underhand grip, keeping your hands shoulder-width apart.

2. Leaning forward slightly, rest your elbows against the inside of your thighs, just above your knees. This will help stabilize your upper body throughout the exercise.

3. Begin the movement by curling the weight upward, bringing your hands toward your shoulders while keeping your upper arms stationary. Focus on contracting your biceps and squeezing them at the top of the movement.

4. Slowly lower the weight back down to the starting position, while maintaining control and keeping tension on your biceps. Avoid fully extending your arms or allowing your shoulders to roll forward.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, aiming for a full range of motion and maintaining proper form throughout the exercise.

Name: Barbell Seated Good morning
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a flat bench with your feet resting flat on the floor, shoulder-width apart. Place a barbell across your upper back, resting it on your traps, similar to how you would position it for a squat.

2. Grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Ensure a secure grip on the barbell, ensuring it does not roll over your neck or shoulders.

3. Slowly, but steadily, hinge forward at your hips, keeping your back straight and maintaining a slight arch in your lower back. It is important to emphasize maintaining good form throughout the exercise.

4. Continue bending forward until your torso is parallel to the floor, or until you feel a good stretch in your hamstrings. At this point, your chest should be pointing towards the floor.

5. Pause for a moment, then engage your glutes and hamstrings to raise your torso back up to the starting position. Remember to keep a slow and controlled movement throughout, avoiding any jerking or sudden movements.

 It is recommended to start with lighter weights and gradually increase the load as you become more comfortable and proficient with the movement.

Note: The barbell seated good morning should be performed with caution, especially if you have any back or hip issues. It is always advised to consult with a fitness professional or trainer to ensure proper form and technique for your specific needs and abilities.

Name: Barbell Seated Overhead Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on a flat bench with your feet planted firmly on the ground and your back straight. Place a barbell behind your head on top of your shoulders, gripping it with an overhand grip, slightly narrower than shoulder-width apart.

2. Lift the barbell off the rack and extend your arms fully, keeping your elbows close to your head. This is your starting position.

3. Slowly lower the barbell behind your head by bending your elbows, ensuring they stay close to your head throughout the movement. Keep your upper arms stationary and only move your forearms.

4. Continue lowering the barbell until your forearms are parallel to the floor and you feel a stretch in your triceps. Pause for a moment, then use your triceps to extend your arms and raise the barbell back to the starting position.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining control and proper form throughout.

Name: Barbell Seated Twist
Description:
1. Start by sitting on the ground with your legs extended straight in front of you. Place a barbell across your shoulders, behind your neck. Hold the barbell with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Engage your core muscles and keep your back straight as you lean slightly back, maintaining a comfortable position.

3. Twist your torso to the right side, bringing the barbell towards your right hip. While doing this, keep your head facing forward and your eyes focused straight ahead.

4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat the movement, this time twisting your torso to the left side, bringing the barbell towards your left hip.

5. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions or as instructed by your fitness professional.

Remember to breathe throughout the exercise and maintain control over the movement. It's important to start with a lighter weight and gradually increase the load as your strength and stability improves.

Name: Barbell Shrug
Description:
1. The exercise 'Barbell Shrug' is a weightlifting exercise that targets the trapezius muscles (the upper back and neck muscles). Here are the steps to perform a barbell shrug:

2. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and position a barbell at thigh level in front of you. Your palms should be facing your thighs, and your grip on the bar should be slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Keeping your back straight and your shoulders relaxed, exhale and lift your shoulders up towards your ears while holding the barbell. The movement should be solely in your shoulders and neck.

4. Hold the contracted position for a brief pause at the top of the movement, squeezing your trapezius muscles.

5. Slowly lower your shoulders back to the starting position while inhaling.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

It's important to note that during a barbell shrug, the movement should be controlled and focused on the trapezius muscles. Avoid using momentum or excessive weight that may compromise your form and increase the risk of injury.

Name: Barbell Side Bent (version 2)
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell positioned on your back, resting behind your shoulders.

2. Slowly bend your body to the side, keeping your legs and hips stationary. The movement should be initiated from your oblique muscles on the side opposite the direction you are leaning.

3. Keep your back straight and your core engaged as you lean to the side, attempting to bring your elbow towards your hip. You should feel a stretch or contraction in your oblique muscles.

4. Hold this position for a second or two, then return to the starting position by slowly straightening your body back up. Repeat the movement on the opposite side.

5. Aim for controlled and deliberate movements, focusing on the contraction and engagement of your oblique muscles throughout the exercise.

Name: Barbell Side Split Squat (version 2)
Description:
1. The Barbell Side Split Squat (version 2) is an exercise that targets the lower body, specifically the quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings. Here are the steps to perform this exercise:

2. Start by standing with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointing forward. Place a barbell behind your shoulders, resting it on your upper back. You can use a pad or towel for added comfort.

3. Take a wide step to the side with your right foot, turning your toes slightly outward. Keep your left foot planted, maintaining balance.

4. Begin the movement by bending your right knee and lowering your body down into a squat position. Ensure that your right knee is directly above your right ankle and your left leg remains straight.

5. Continue descending until your right thigh is parallel to the ground or as low as you can comfortably go. Keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

6. Push through your right heel to rise back up, extending your right leg and bringing your feet back together.

7. Repeat the same steps on the other side, stepping out with your left foot and performing the squat.


Tips:
- Maintain good balance and stability by keeping your gaze forward and your chest up.
- Keep your core tight to provide additional support and stability.
- Control the movement and avoid letting your knee cave inward during the squat.
- Adjust the weight on the barbell according to your strength and comfort level.

Name: Barbell Standing Leg Calf Raise
Description:
1. Start by placing a barbell on your upper back, resting it securely across your shoulders. Make sure to keep a firm grip on the barbell with your hands, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointed forward. This will be your starting position.

3. Raise your heels off the ground by extending your ankles as high as possible, while keeping your knees straight. This is the main movement of the exercise.

4. Pause at the top of the movement and hold for a second, then slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

5. Keep your core engaged, your back straight, and maintain a controlled and steady motion throughout the exercise. Adjust the weight on the barbell according to your strength and fitness level to ensure proper form and avoid any strain or injury.

Name: Barbell Standing Overhead Triceps Extension
Description:
1. The Barbell Standing Overhead Triceps Extension is an exercise that primarily targets the triceps muscles. Here are the steps to perform this exercise:

2. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp a barbell with an overhand grip, placing your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Lift the barbell above your head and fully extend your arms. This is your starting position.

4. Keeping your upper arms close to your head and elbows stationary, slowly lower the barbell behind your head by bending your elbows. Maintain control and avoid swinging the weight.

5. Once you feel a stretch in your triceps, pause for a moment, and then begin to raise the barbell back to the starting position by extending the elbows and contracting the triceps.

6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Note: It's important to keep your core engaged and back straight throughout the exercise. Adjust the weight and repetitions according to your fitness level and goals.

Name: Barbell Standing Reverse Grip Curl
Description:
1. Stand up straight with a barbell in your hands, palms facing downward and hands spaced slightly closer than shoulder-width apart.

2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and exhale as you curl the barbell upwards toward your chest.

3. Hold for a brief pause, squeezing your biceps, then inhale as you slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position.

4. Keep your upper arms stationary throughout the movement, only allowing your forearms to move.

5. Repeat the motion for the desired number of reps.

Name: Barbell Standing Twist
Description:
1. Stand upright while holding a barbell across your upper back, resting it on your traps and shoulders.

2. Keeping your core engaged, twist your upper body to the right, pivoting on your left foot while allowing your right foot to pivot slightly.

3. Return to the center and then twist to the left, pivoting on your right foot and allowing your left foot to pivot slightly.

4. Maintain good posture and controlled movement throughout, keeping the barbell steady on your upper back.

Name: Barbell Standing Wide-grip Curl
Description:
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with a wide grip, palms facing forward.

2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and exhale as you curl the barbell upwards toward your shoulders.

3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement, then inhale as you lower the barbell down with control.

4. Maintain a stable upper body and avoid swinging the barbell for proper isolation of the biceps.

Name: Barbell Step-up
Description:
1. Place a barbell across your upper back, resting it on your traps and shoulders.

2. Stand in front of a sturdy platform or bench.

3. Step onto the platform with one foot, pushing through your heel to lift your body up.

4. Fully extend your hip and knee on the stepping leg and bring the other foot up to stand on the platform.

5. Step back down with the non-leading leg first and then follow with the leading leg to return to the starting position.

6. Alternate the leading leg for each repetition.

Name: Barbell Stiff Leg Good Morning
Description:
1. Place a barbell across your upper back, resting it on your traps and shoulders.

2. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and a slight bend in your knees.

3. Keeping your back straight and core engaged, hinge at your hips and lower your torso forward until it's almost parallel to the ground.

4. Keep your knees slightly bent and feel a stretch in your hamstrings.

5. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to return to the upright position.

Name: Barbell Straight Leg Deadlift
Description:
1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and hold the barbell in front of your thighs with an overhand grip.

2. Keeping a slight bend in your knees, hinge at your hips and lower the barbell down towards the ground.

3. Lower the barbell while keeping your back flat and core engaged, feeling a stretch in your hamstrings.

4. Reverse the movement by driving your hips forward and standing up straight.

5. Keep the barbell close to your body throughout the movement.

Name: Barbell Sumo Deadlift
Synergist: Adductor Magnus, Soleus, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outward.

2. Place a barbell in front of you and grip it with your hands inside your knees using an overhand or mixed grip.

3. Keep your back flat, chest up, and core engaged as you lift the barbell off the ground.

4. Drive through your heels and extend your hips and knees to stand up straight.

5. Lower the barbell back down with control, maintaining the same form.

Name: Barbell Reverse Grip Bent over Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Hold a barbell with a reverse grip (palms facing upward) and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart.

2. Hinge at your hips to bend forward, keeping your back flat and knees slightly bent.

3. Pull the barbell towards your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together.

4. Lower the barbell back down with control, maintaining proper form.

5. Keep your elbows close to your body throughout the movement.

Name: Barbell Upright Row
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Anterior, Infraspinatus, Serratus Anterior, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Hold a barbell with an overhand grip, hands slightly closer than shoulder-width apart.

2. Stand with the barbell in front of your thighs.

3. Lift the barbell by raising your elbows towards the ceiling, keeping it close to your body.

4. Continue lifting until the barbell reaches chest level, then lower it back down with control.

5. Keep your core engaged and avoid using momentum to lift the barbell.

Name: Barbell Wrist Curl
Description:
1. Sit on a bench with forearms resting on your thighs and palms facing up, holding a barbell.

2. Allow the barbell to roll down to your fingertips, then curl it back up by flexing your wrists.

3. Keep your forearms steady throughout the movement and focus on the wrist muscles.

Name: Bench Dip (knees bent)
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Latissimus Dorsi, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Sit on the edge of a bench and place your hands on the bench beside your hips.

2. Slide your hips forward off the bench and bend your knees at a 90-degree angle.

3. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the floor.

4. Push back up to the starting position using your triceps, keeping your back close to the bench.

Name: Cable Alternate Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Attach a rope handle to a high pulley on a cable machine.

2. Stand facing the machine, holding one end of the rope with one hand

3. Extend one arm down and back, focusing on your triceps, then switch to the other arm.

4. Keep your upper arms stationary and only move your forearms throughout the exercise. Perform the motion of unsheathing a katana.

Name: Cable Bar Lateral Pulldown
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Attach a wide-grip bar to the high pulley of a cable machine.

2. Sit down and grip the bar with your hands wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Pull the bar down to your upper chest while squeezing your shoulder blades together.

4. Slowly release the bar back up, maintaining control and tension in your lats.

Name: Cable Bench Press
Target: Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Attach handles to the high pulleys of a cable machine and set up a bench in the middle.

2. Lie on the bench and grip the handles with your palms facing away from you.

3. Push the handles away from your body while extending your arms, mimicking a bench press.

4. Slowly bring the handles back towards your chest while maintaining control.

Name: Cable Concentration Extension (on knee)
Description:
1. Attach a rope handle to a low pulley on a cable machine.

2. Kneel down and hold the rope handle with one hand, palm facing up, and your elbow bent.

3. Extend your arm outward while keeping your upper arm stationary, focusing on your triceps.

4. Slowly return to the starting position without letting the weight stack touch down.

Name: Cable Cross-over Lateral Pulldown
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Attach D-handles to the high pulleys of a cable machine.

2. Stand in the middle and grab the handles with your arms extended out to the sides.

3. Pull the handles down and in towards your hips while squeezing your lats.

4. Gradually release the handles back up, maintaining control over the movement.

Name: Cable Cross-over Revers Fly
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Infraspinatus, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Set the pulleys to the lowest position on a cable machine and attach D-handles.

2. Stand in between the pulleys and hold the handles with your arms crossed in front of you.

3. Open your arms out to the sides, squeezing your rear deltoids as you pull.

4. Bring your arms back to the starting position while maintaining control.

Name: Cable Cross-over Variation
Target: Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Adjust the pulleys to a high position on a cable machine and attach appropriate handles.

2. Stand in the center and grasp the handles with your arms slightly bent, positioned at shoulder height.

3. Pull the handles down and together in a diagonal motion across your body's front.

4. Slowly reverse the movement, stretching your chest muscles before the next repetition.

Name: Cable Decline Fly
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head
Description:
1. Set the pulleys to a low position and attach D-handles on a cable machine.

2. Lie on a decline bench and hold the handles with your arms extended out to the sides.

3. Bring your arms up and together, meeting above your chest, while squeezing your chest muscles.

4. Lower your arms back down in a controlled manner, feeling a stretch in your chest.

Name: Cable Front Raise
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior
Description:
1. Attach a bar handle to a low pulley on a cable machine.

2. Stand facing away from the machine and hold the bar with both hands

3. Lift the bar forward and upward, raising your arms until they are parallel to the floor.

4. Lower the bar back down under control, focusing on your front deltoids.

Name: Cable Front Shoulder Raise
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior
Description:
1. Attach D-handles to a low pulley on the cable machine.

2. Stand facing the machine and hold the handles in front of your thighs, palms facing down.

3. Lift the handles forward and upward until your arms are parallel to the floor.

4. Lower the handles back down under control, targeting your front shoulder muscles.

Name: Cable Hammer Curl (with rope)
Description:
1. Attach a rope handle to a low pulley on the cable machine.

2. Stand facing the machine and hold the rope handles with a neutral grip (palms facing each other).

3. Curl the rope handles up towards your shoulders, keeping your upper arms steady.

4. Slowly lower the handles back down, feeling the contraction in your biceps.

Name: Cable Hip Adduction
Description:
1. Attach an ankle strap to your ankle and set the cable machine to a low position.

2. Stand sideways to the machine, with the working leg away from the machine.

3. Move your working leg across your body, pulling against the resistance.

4. Bring your leg back to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Name: Cable Incline Bench Press
Description:
1. Attach D-handles to the low pulleys of the cable machine.

2. Lie on an incline bench facing away from the machine, and hold the handles at chest level.

3. Push the handles forward and upward, extending your arms.

4. Slowly bring the handles back towards your chest, maintaining control.

Name: Cable Incline Fly
Description:
1. Set the pulleys to a high position on the cable machine and attach D-handles.

2. Lie on an incline bench facing the machine, holding the handles with your arms slightly bent.

3. Open your arms out to the sides, squeezing your chest muscles.

4. Bring your arms back to the starting position while maintaining control.

Name: Cable Incline Pushdown
Synergist: Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Teres Major
Description:
1. Attach a bar handle to the high pulley of the cable machine.

2. Sit on an incline bench facing the machine, and hold the bar with your hands close together.

3. Push the bar downward by extending your arms, focusing on your triceps.

4. Slowly let the bar rise back up, keeping control over the movement.

Name: Cable Incline Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of the cable machine.

2. Sit on an incline bench facing away from the machine and hold the rope with both hands.

3. Extend your arms overhead while holding the rope, focusing on your triceps.

4. Lower the rope back down behind your head, feeling the stretch, and then extend again.

Name: Cable Kneeling Crunch
Description:
1. Attach a rope handle to a high pulley on the cable machine.

2. Kneel down and hold the rope behind your head with your elbows bent.

3. Crunch your torso down towards your knees, contracting your abdominal muscles.

4. Slowly return to the starting position, maintaining tension on your abs.

Name: Cable Kneeling Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Attach a bar handle to a high pulley on the cable machine. You can use a bench to give you stability.

2. Kneel down and hold the bar with both hands behind your head.

3. Extend your arms upward, focusing on your triceps, while keeping your upper arms still.

4. Lower the bar back down behind your head, feeling the stretch in your triceps.

Name: Cable Lateral Raise
Description:
1. Stand in front of the cable machine and hold a handle in each hand with your arms down at your sides.

2. Maintain a slight bend in your elbows and engage your core.

3. Raise both arms out to the sides at shoulder level, while keeping your palms facing downward.

4. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, feeling the tension in your lateral deltoids.

5. Lower both arms back down under control, maintaining proper form and controlled movement.

Name: Cable Low Fly
Description:
1. This exercise targets the upper part of your chest

2. Stand facing a cable machine with the pulleys set to the lowest position.

3. Grab the handles attached to the pulleys with an underhand grip.

4. Engage your core muscles and maintain a slight bend in your knees.

5. Keeping your arms straight, pull the cables up and out to your sides while maintaining a slight bend in your elbows.

6. Slowly lower the cables back to the starting position, ensuring that your arms remain slightly bent throughout the movement.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, breathing deeply, and focusing on the muscles being targeted.

Name: Cable Low Seated Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Sit on the seat facing the cable machine and place your feet on the footrests.

2. Grasp the cable handles with an overhand grip, palms facing down.

3. While keeping your back straight, lean slightly backwards to create tension on the cable. This is your starting position.

4. Pull the cable handles towards your body by retracting your shoulder blades and squeezing your back muscles.

5. Pause for a moment when you have pulled the handles as far back as possible, ensuring a full contraction in your back muscles.

6. Slowly release the tension and return to the starting position, allowing your arms to fully extend without completely relaxing your back muscles.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps, maintaining proper form throughout.

Name: Cable Lying Extension Pullover (with rope attachment)
Synergist: Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Teres Major, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by attaching a rope handle to a low-pulley cable machine. This should be done at a height that allows you to comfortably lie down and hold onto the handle above your head.

2. Lie down on a bench or mat, facing up, with your head towards the cable machine. Grab the rope handle with both hands, palms facing each other, and extend your arms fully above your chest. This is your starting position.

3. Keeping your arms straight, slowly lower the rope handle towards the floor by allowing your shoulders to hyperextend. Maintain control while you lower the rope until it is parallel to the floor, or until you feel a comfortable stretch in your chest and back muscles.

4. Once you have reached the stretched position, engage your chest and back muscles to pull the rope handle back up towards the starting position. Focus on using your muscles to control the movement, rather than relying solely on momentum.

5. Squeeze your chest and back muscles at the top of the movement, holding for a brief moment to maximize the contraction.

Remember to breathe throughout the exercise and maintain proper form, focusing on using your muscles rather than straining with your joints.

Name: Cable Lying Fly
Target: Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Lie down on a bench with your back flat and your feet planted firmly on the floor.

2. Grasp the cable handles attached to the pulleys with an overhand grip, keeping your arms extended straight out in front of your chest.

3. Maintain a slight bend in your elbows and begin to slowly lower your arms out to the sides in a wide arc.

4. Continue moving your arms until they are slightly below shoulder level, feeling a stretch in your chest muscles.

5. Reverse the motion and slowly raise your arms back to the starting position, focusing on using your chest muscles to bring them back together.


Remember to breathe throughout the exercise, exhaling as you lower your arms and inhaling as you raise them back up.

Name: Cable Lying Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Step 1: Begin by lying flat on your back on a workout bench or mat, with your feet planted firmly on the ground.

2. Step 2: Grasp a cable bar with an overhand grip and extend your arms straight up towards the ceiling, keeping your elbows in 90 degree angle.

3. Step 3: Inhale as you slowly lower the cable bar towards your forehead, making sure to keep your upper arms stationary throughout the movement.

4. Step 4: Exhale as you engage your triceps to extend your arms back up to the starting position, fully contracting your triceps at the top of the movement.

5. Step 5: Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps, focusing on controlling the movement and maintaining proper form throughout. 

Remember to maintain proper form, control the movement, and focus on engaging the triceps throughout the exercise.

Name: Cable Middle Fly
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head
Description:
1. Attach the appropriate weight resistance to the cable machine. Adjust the handles to a suitable height, usually around chest level.

2. Stand in the middle of the cable machine, with one foot slightly in front of the other for stability.

3. Grasp the handles with an overhand grip and extend your arms out to the sides, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. This is your starting position.

4. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, exhale and bring your arms forward in a sweeping motion, crossing them in front of your body. Try to maintain a slight bend in your elbows throughout the movement.

5. Pause for a brief moment when your arms cross in front of your chest.

6. Inhale and slowly return to the starting position by reversing the motion, controlling the weight resistance as you allow your arms to move back out to the sides.

User: Stand in the middle of the cable machine with one foot slightly in front of the other. Grasp the handles with an overhand grip and extend your arms out to the sides. 
Cross your arms in front of your body, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Pause momentarily.
Extend your arms back out to the sides, returning to the starting position.

Name: Cable One Arm Curl
Description:
1. Begin by standing upright in front of a cable machine, with your feet hip-width apart.

2. Grab the cable handle with one hand, making sure your palm is facing up and your arm is fully extended.

3. Keep your upper arm close to your body as you slowly curl the cable handle towards your shoulder, exhaling during the contraction.

4. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, ensuring that your bicep muscle is fully contracted.

5. Slowly lower the cable handle back to the starting position, inhaling as you extend your arm fully.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, and then switch arms to perform the exercise on the other side.

Note: Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, focusing on the bicep muscle and avoiding any swinging or jerking motions.

Name: Cable One Arm Lateral Raise
Description:
1. Begin by attaching a handle to the low pulley cable of a cable machine.

2. Stand with your side facing the machine and your feet shoulder-width apart.

3. Grasp the handle with one hand and position your arm straight down in front of you, while maintaining a slight bend at the elbow.

4. Keep your core engaged and your back straight as you slowly raise the cable handle out to the side, lifting your arm upward until it reaches shoulder level.

5. Pause at the top for a brief moment while squeezing your shoulder muscle, then slowly lower the cable handle back to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions and then switch arms to perform the same movement on the other side.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise and avoid using excessive weight that could compromise your technique.

Name: Cable Overhead Triceps Extension (rope attachment)
Description:
1. Attach a rope handle to the low pulley of the cable machine and set the weight.

2. Stand facing away from the machine and hold the rope with both hands, palms facing up.

3. Begin with your upper arms close to your head and your elbows bent at around 90 degrees.

4. Your hands should be positioned over your head, with the rope hanging behind you.

5. Keeping your upper arms stationary, extend your forearms by straightening your elbows.

6. Fully extend your arms while raising the rope upward, feeling the triceps contraction.

7. Slowly bend your elbows to return to the starting position, lowering the rope behind your head.

8. Maintain control and proper form throughout the movement.

Name: Cable Preacher Curl
Description:
1. Sit on a preacher curl bench facing a cable machine with the pulley set to the lowest position.

2. Place your upper arms and chest on the pad of the preacher bench while grabbing the cable attachment with an underhand grip.

3. Start with your arms fully extended and be sure to maintain a slight bend in your elbows throughout the movement.

4. Keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the cable attachment as you contract your biceps. Focus on bringing the attachment towards your shoulders.

5. Pause for a brief moment at the top of the movement, then inhale as you slowly lower the cable attachment back down to the starting position.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, maintaining proper form and control throughout.

Name: Cable Wide Pulldown
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Sit down on a cable pulldown machine and adjust the thigh pads to hold your legs in place.

2. Grab the wide bar attachment with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Lean back slightly, engaging your core muscles, and keep your chest up throughout the exercise.

4. Inhale as you pull the bar down towards your upper chest by squeezing your shoulder blades together, and exhale as you release the bar back up to the starting position.

5. Keep your elbows pointed out to the sides and maintain a controlled, smooth motion throughout the exercise.

Name: Cable Pulldown
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Sit down on the cable pulldown machine and adjust the knee pad so that it rests comfortably against your thighs.
