3. Grasp the barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing you) and hands shoulder-width apart.

4. Pull the barbell towards your chest by squeezing your shoulder blades together and keeping your elbows close to your body.

5. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position.

6. Repeat this exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Smith Reverse Calf Raises
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet hip-width apart underneath the Smith machine bar.

2. Position your lower legs, specifically your calves, on a weight bench set a short distance away from the bar. Your knees should be slightly bent, and your toes pointing upwards.

3. Hold onto the bar with both hands to maintain stability and balance throughout the exercise.

4. Slowly lower your heels towards the ground, feeling a stretch in your calf muscles.

5. Once you reach the bottom of the movement, use your calf muscles to push your heels up as high as possible.

6. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, then lower your heels back down to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Final user executing the exercise:

7. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart underneath the Smith machine bar.

8. Place your calves on a weight bench in front of you.

9. Hold onto the bar with both hands for stability.

10. Lower your heels towards the ground, feeling the stretch in your calves.

11. Push your heels up as high as possible, using your calf muscles.

12. Pause briefly at the top, then slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position.

Name: Smith Reverse-grip Press
Target: Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Stand in front of a Smith machine and adjust the bar height to a position slightly below shoulder level.

2. Stand facing the machine and reach up to grip the bar with an underhand, reverse grip, with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Keep your feet planted firmly on the ground and engage your core for stability.

4. Inhale, then slowly lower the bar down towards your chest by bending your elbows, making sure to keep your wrists in a stable position.

5. Exhale and extend your arms, pushing the bar back up to the starting position.

Name: Smith Seated Shoulder Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a bench with your back fully supported and your feet planted firmly on the ground.

2. Grab a pair of dumbbells and hold them with an overhand grip at shoulder level, palms facing forward.

3. Engage your core muscles and press the dumbbells directly upwards until your arms are fully extended, but not locked out.

4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, making sure to control the movement and not let gravity take over.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form throughout.

Name: Smith Shoulder Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Set up the Smith machine with the bar at shoulder height.

2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, directly under the bar.

3. Position your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width on the bar, with an overhand grip.

4. Engage your core and press the bar upwards, extending your arms fully overhead.

5. Slowly lower the bar back down to the starting position, allowing your elbows to bend slightly.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps while maintaining proper form and control.

Name: Smith Shrug
Description:
1. Stand in front of a smith machine, with your feet shoulder-width apart.

2. Position the barbell on the hooks of the machine at around chest height.

3. Grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

4. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees.

5. Raise your shoulders towards your ears as high as you can, while keeping your arms straight.

6. Hold the contraction at the top for a second, then slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Name: Smith Single Leg Split Squat
Description:
1. Start by standing in front of a Smith machine, with one foot positioned slightly in front of the other and the barbell resting across your upper back.

2. Lift one foot off the ground and extend it straight out in front of you, keeping it parallel to the floor. This will be your starting position.

3. Slowly lower your body down by bending your front knee, while keeping your back knee off the ground and maintaining a straight posture. Keep lowering until your front thigh is parallel to the floor.

4. Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement, and then push through your front heel to return to the starting position.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, and then switch legs to complete the set.

Name: Smith Sprint Lunge
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet hip-width apart, facing the Smith machine. Grasp the barbell with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Take a large step forward with your right foot, bending your right knee to create a 90-degree angle. Ensure that your left knee is positioned slightly above the floor or lightly touching it. This is your starting lunge position.

3. Push off with your right foot and explode into a powerful jump, using your arms to help propel you upwards.

4. While in mid-air, quickly switch your leg positions, bringing your left foot forward and your right foot back. Remember to keep your knees bent at a 90-degree angle as you land.

5. Upon landing, immediately drop into a lunge position with your left foot forward and right foot back. Repeat the explosive jump, once again switching your leg positions mid-air.

Name: Smith Squat
Description:
1. Start by standing inside the Smith machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. Ensure that the bar is resting on the hooks at an appropriate height for your comfort.

2. Position yourself under the bar, with the barbell resting on your upper back. Place your hands on the bar a slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, gripping it firmly.

3. Keeping your core engaged and your back straight, slowly lower your body by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. Imagine sitting back into an imaginary chair. Aim to go as low as you comfortably can, ensuring that your knees do not extend beyond your toes.

4. Once you have reached the lowest point, pause for a moment, then push through your heels to rise back up to the starting position. As you ascend, keep your back straight and your chest lifted.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining a controlled and fluid motion throughout.

Remember to always consult a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercise, especially if you have any underlying medical conditions or concerns.

Name: Smith Standing Behind Head Military Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by setting up the Smith machine bar at shoulder height or slightly higher. Position yourself in front of the bar, facing away from the machine.

2. Reach behind your head and grip the bar with an overhand grip, wider than shoulder-width apart. Your palms should be facing forward.

3. Stand tall with your feet shoulder-width apart, engage your core, and keep your back straight.

4. Keeping your elbows pointed forward and your forearms perpendicular to the floor, slowly press the bar upward until your arms are fully extended overhead.

5. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the bar back to the starting position behind your head.

Name: Smith Standing Military Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by adjusting the height of the bar on the Smith machine to your shoulder level.

2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, positioning yourself directly under the bar.

3. Grip the bar with an overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

4. Take a deep breath and brace your core muscles.

5. Press the bar upwards using your shoulder and arm strength until your arms are fully extended overhead.

6. Slowly lower the bar back down to the starting position by bending your elbows.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Smith Upright Row
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Anterior, Infraspinatus, Serratus Anterior, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart, facing the Smith machine.

2. Grasp the Smith barbell with an overhand grip, slightly narrower than shoulder-width apart.

3. Keep your arms fully extended and your back straight, engaging your core for stability.

4. Engage your shoulders and pull the barbell straight up towards your chin, leading with your elbows.

5. Pause at the top of the movement for a brief second, then slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position, maintaining control throughout.

Name: Triceps Dip
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Latissimus Dorsi, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Sit on the edge of a sturdy chair or bench, placing your hands shoulder-width apart next to your hips.

2. Slide your buttocks off the front of the chair, keeping your feet flat on the ground with your knees bent at a 90-degree angle.

3. Slowly lower your body down by bending your elbows, aiming to bring your upper arms parallel to the floor. Keep your back close to the chair and avoid leaning forward.

4. Once you have reached the lowest position, pause for a moment before pushing yourself back up to the starting position by extending your arms. Make sure to maintain control throughout the movement.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring that your triceps muscles are engaged and doing the majority of the work.

6. Remember to breathe steadily throughout the exercise and keep your core muscles engaged to maintain stability.

Name: Triceps Dips Floor
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Latissimus Dorsi, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Start by sitting on the edge of a sturdy chair or bench with your feet firmly planted on the floor.

2. Place your hands shoulder-width apart on the edge of the chair, fingers facing forward, and extend your legs straight out in front of you.

3. While keeping your back close to the chair, slowly lower your body downwards by bending your elbows. Your elbows should be pointed directly behind you.

4. Continue lowering your body until your upper arms are parallel to the floor, making sure to avoid hunching your shoulders.

5. Once you reach this bottom position, push yourself back up to the starting position by extending your elbows. Make sure to keep your core engaged and maintain proper form throughout the movement.

Remember to consult a fitness professional before attempting any new exercises to ensure proper form and prevent injury. Good luck with your workout!

Name: Twin handle parallel grip lat pulldown
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Sit down on the lat pulldown machine and adjust the thigh pads so they sit comfortably against your thighs.

2. Grasp the twin handles with a parallel grip, palms facing each other and your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Engage your core and maintain a neutral spine as you pull the handles down towards your upper chest, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together.

4. Pause for a moment at the bottom of the movement, feeling the contraction in your back muscles.

5. Slowly reverse the movement and allow the handles to rise back up to the starting position, keeping control throughout the entire range of motion.

Remember to breathe throughout the exercise and focus on form and control rather than speed or using excessive weights. If you have any discomfort or pain during the exercise, stop immediately and consult with a professional.

Name: Vertical Leg Raise (on parallel bars)
Synergist: Adductor Brevis, Adductor Longus, Pectineous, Sartorius, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Start by standing in between the parallel bars with your arms extended straight and gripping the bars firmly.

2. Lift both of your legs off the ground, while keeping them straight and together. Your body should be hanging vertically between the bars.

3. Continue to raise your legs until they are parallel to the ground, or as high as you can comfortably lift them without straining.

4. Hold the position for a few seconds, focusing on engaging your core and abdominal muscles. This will help strengthen your core and improve stability.

5. Slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position, keeping them straight and controlled. Try to avoid swinging or using momentum to lift or lower your legs.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout each repetition.

Remember to always listen to your body and adjust the difficulty level as needed. It's important to start with a range of motion that feels comfortable to you and gradually increase the challenge as you get stronger.

Name: Weighted Bench Dip
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Latissimus Dorsi, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Begin by placing a bench firmly against a wall or secure surface. Position yourself facing away from the bench with your arms shoulder-width apart and hands gripping the edge of the bench.

2. Extend your legs forward, keeping them straight and resting your heels on the ground. This will be your starting position.

3. Slowly lower your body by bending your elbows, allowing your upper arms to move parallel to the floor. Continue to lower yourself until your elbows reach a 90-degree angle, creating a 90-degree bend in your arms.

4. Pause briefly in this lowered position, feeling the stretch and contraction in your triceps. Make sure to keep your back close to the bench throughout the movement.

5. Next, engage your triceps and push yourself back up to the starting position by extending your arms fully, ensuring a straight line from your shoulders to your hands.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on controlled movements and maintaining proper form throughout.

Remember to consult a fitness professional or trainer before attempting this exercise to ensure it is suitable for your individual fitness level and to receive any necessary modifications or instructions.

Name: Weighted Lying Side Lifting Head (with head harness)
Description:
1. Lie down on your side with your head resting on a cushion or mat.

2. Secure a head harness around your head and attach a weight plate or resistance band to the harness.

3. With your body in a straight line, engage your core muscles to maintain stability.

4. Lift your head off the ground, using the muscles on the side of your neck, while keeping your neck aligned with your spine.

5. Hold the lifted position for a brief moment, ensuring you feel a contraction in the targeted muscles.

6. Slowly lower your head back down to the starting position, maintaining control and focusing on your muscles throughout the movement.

It is important to note that the instructions provided are a general outline of the exercise. It is recommended to consult with a fitness professional or trainer for personalized instructions, appropriate weight selection, and any modifications that may be necessary based on individual fitness levels or limitations.

Name: Weighted Seated Neck Extension (with head harness)
Synergist: Levator Scapulae, Sternocleidomastoid, Trapezius Upper Fibers
Description:
1. Sit on a chair or bench with your back straight and place a head harness around your head.

2. Attach a weight plate to the front of the head harness, securing it in place.

3. Keep your hands rested on your thighs and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

4. Slowly lower your head forward towards your chest, feeling a stretch in the back of your neck.

5. Engage the muscles in the back of your neck to lift your head back up to an upright position.

6. Repeat this movement for the desired number of repetitions as instructed by your fitness trainer.

Remember to focus on proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Cable kickback
Description:
1. Stand facing a cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart and a slight bend in your knees.

2. Position your hands on the cable handle and bring it to a comfortable height in front of you.

3. Engage your core muscles and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

4. With a controlled motion, extend your leg straight back, keeping it parallel to the ground.

5. Squeeze your glute muscles at the top of the movement and hold for a second.

6. Slowly lower your leg back to starting position, maintaining control and ensuring your foot doesn't touch the ground.

7. Repeat the movement with the same leg for the desired number of repetitions, then switch to the opposite leg.

Name: Cable seated row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Sit on the machine with your feet firmly planted on the footrests.

2. Grab the handles with an overhand grip and keep your back straight.

3. Start the movement by retracting your shoulder blades and pulling the handles towards your body.

4. Squeeze your back muscles at the peak of the contraction and hold for a moment.

5. Slowly release the handles back to the starting position, allowing your arms to fully extend.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and engaging your back muscles throughout the exercise.

Name: Dumbbell Upright Shoulder External Rotation
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in your right hand.

2. Bend your right elbow and lift the dumbbell towards your shoulder, keeping your arm close to your body.

3. Keeping your elbow bent at a 90-degree angle, slowly rotate your right forearm outward, away from your body, while keeping your upper arm still.

4. Continue the rotation until your forearm is parallel to the ground, ensuring that your elbow stays at a 90-degree angle throughout the movement.

5. Hold for a brief moment at the top, feeling a contraction in your shoulder muscles, and then slowly return the dumbbell back to the starting position.

6. Repeat the same steps with your left arm to complete one set.

Remember to start with a weight that is appropriate for your fitness level and gradually increase it as you become stronger. It's important to maintain proper form and control throughout the exercise to target the correct muscles and minimize the risk of injury.

Name: Weighted Hanging leg-hip raise
Synergist: Adductor Brevis, Adductor Longus, Iliopsoas, Obliques, Pectineous, Sartorius, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Begin by attaching a weighted plate or dumbbell to a cable machine or weight belt, ensuring that it's securely fastened.

2. Hang from a vertical bar or pull-up bar, ensuring that your body is fully stretched out and your legs are straight down.

3. Engage your core muscles and stabilize your torso by keeping your back straight and shoulders relaxed.

4. In a controlled manner, exhale as you initiate the movement by lifting your legs upward, using your hip flexors to drive the motion. Continue until your thighs are parallel to the ground or as close as possible.

5. Hold the raised position for a brief moment, focusing on squeezing your abdominal muscles.

6. Slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position, while maintaining a controlled motion and avoiding any swinging or excessive momentum. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions. 

Remember, it's important to maintain proper form throughout the exercise and listen to your body's limitations to avoid any potential strain or injury.

Name: Cable Curl
Description:
1. Stand facing a cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent, and core engaged.

2. Grasp the cable attachment with an underhand grip, palms facing upward, and hands shoulder-width apart.

3. Keep your elbows close to your sides and avoid using your back or shoulders to lift the weight.

4. Slowly curl the cable attachment towards your shoulders by flexing your biceps, while keeping your upper arms stationary.

5. Fully contract your biceps at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the cable attachment back to the starting position, keeping tension on your biceps throughout the entire motion.

Remember, always consult with a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercise to ensure proper form and technique.

Name: Lever Shoulder Press (plate loaded) version 2
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Sit down on the seat of the lever shoulder press machine with your back pressed firmly against the backrest.

2. Adjust the seat according to your height so that the handles are level with your upper chest.

3. Place your feet flat on the floor with your knees bent at a 90-degree angle.

4. Grasp the handles with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

5. Exhale and push the handles upward in a controlled manner, extending your arms fully without locking your elbows.

6. Pause briefly at the top of the movement and then inhale as you slowly lower the handles back down to the starting position.

7. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining a smooth and controlled motion throughout.

Remember to adjust the weight plates loaded on the machine according to your fitness level and ability. If you have any doubts about performing this exercise or if you experience discomfort or pain, it is recommended to seek guidance from a fitness professional.

Name: Butt-ups
Description:
1. Lie flat on your back with your legs extended straight and your arms resting by your sides.

2. Bend your knees and place your feet flat on the ground, keeping them hip-width apart.

3. Engage your core muscles by pulling your belly button in towards your spine.

4. Slowly lift your hips off the ground, squeezing your glutes and using your lower abdominal muscles to drive the movement.

5. Pause for a second at the top of the movement, making sure to maintain a straight line from your knees to your shoulders.

6. Lower your hips back down to the starting position, focusing on controlling the movement and not letting your back arch.

If you have any questions or need further clarification, feel free to ask.

Name: Tuck Crunch
Description:
1. Lie down on your back on a yoga mat and extend both legs straight out in front of you.

2. Bend your knees and bring them towards your chest, creating a 90-degree angle at the hip joint.

3. Place your hands behind your head, interlocking your fingers, and keep your elbows wide open.

4. Engage your core muscles by contracting your abdominal muscles.

5. Lift your head, neck, and shoulder blades off the mat, aiming to touch your knees with your elbows.

6. Hold this position for a few seconds while maintaining the contraction in your abs.

7. Slowly lower your upper body back down to the starting position, keeping your core engaged throughout.

8. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps.

Name: Reverse Crunch
Description:
1. Lie down on your back with your legs extended and your arms by your sides.

2. Bend your knees and lift your legs off the ground while keeping them together.

3. Bring your knees towards your chest, curling your pelvis towards your ribs.

4. Exhale as you lift your hips off the ground and contract your abdominal muscles.

5. Pause for a moment at the top, then slowly lower your hips back down to the starting position.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember to maintain control and engage your core throughout the exercise.

Name: Cable Reverse Crunch
Description:
1. Start by attaching a cable handle to a low pulley on a cable machine.

2. Sit down on the floor facing away from the machine and grab the cable handle with both hands, placing them behind your head.

3. Bend your knees and lift your feet off the ground, bringing your thighs perpendicular to the floor. This is your starting position.

4. Slowly contract your abs as you curl your upper body towards your knees, rounding your lower back and lifting your shoulder blades off the ground.

5. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, squeezing your abs.

6. Slowly lower your upper body back to the starting position, keeping tension on your abs throughout the exercise.

7. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Cable Standing Crunch (with rope attachment)
Description:
1. Start by attaching a rope handle to a cable machine set at a low height. Stand facing the machine, with your feet shoulder-width apart.

2. Grasp the handle with both hands and extend your arms straight in front of you, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. This is your starting position.

3. Engage your core muscles by drawing your belly button in towards your spine.

4. Slowly bend at your waist, bringing your upper body down towards your thighs while keeping your arms straight. Feel the contraction in your abdominal muscles as you perform the crunch.

5. Pause for a brief moment at the bottom position, then slowly return to the starting position by extending your torso back up to a vertical position. Focus on using your abdominal muscles to initiate the movement rather than relying on your arms.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining controlled and deliberate movements throughout. Remember to breathe continuously while performing the cable standing crunch to ensure proper oxygen flow to your muscles.

Name: Lever Parallel Chest Press
Description:
1. Begin by adjusting the lever parallel chest press machine according to your height and comfort.

2. Sit on the machine and position your feet flat on the floor, ensuring a stable base.

3. Grasp the two handles with your palms facing downwards and your hands shoulder-width apart.

4. Keeping your back straight and shoulders relaxed, exhale and push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended in front of you.

5. Pause for a moment at the end of the movement, feeling the contraction in your chest muscles.

6. Slowly inhale as you bring the handles back towards your chest, bending your arms at the elbows.

7. Repeat these steps for your desired number of repetitions.

Name: Lever Pec Deck Fly
Description:
1. Sit down on the lever pec deck machine and adjust the seat height so that your feet are flat on the floor and your knees are at a 90-degree angle.

2. Place your forearms on the padded lever arms, with your upper arms parallel to the floor and your elbows at a 90-degree angle.

3. Slowly exhale and push the lever arms together in a controlled manner, allowing your chest muscles to contract. Focus on squeezing your chest muscles throughout the movement.

4. Hold the peak contraction for a brief second, feeling the stretch in your chest muscles.

5. Inhale and slowly release the lever arms back to the starting position, controlling the movement to avoid any jerking or bouncing.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps, maintaining proper form and controlled movements throughout.

Name: Lever Standing Hip Extension
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. Place your hands on a stable surface, such as a squat rack or barbell, to help with balance if needed.

2. Engage your core muscles by pulling your belly button in towards your spine. This will help stabilize your spine during the exercise.

3. Keeping your right leg straight, lift it off the ground and extend it straight back behind you. Your foot should be flexed, and your toes pointing towards the ground.

4. Squeeze your glutes (butt muscles) as you raise your leg, focusing on using the muscles in your hip to perform the movement.

5. Slowly lower your leg back to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the entire range of motion. Be mindful not to let your lower back arch or your upper body to lean forward.

6. Repeat the movement with your left leg, completing the desired number of repetitions for each leg.

Remember to breathe throughout the exercise, inhaling during the lowering phase and exhaling during the raising phase. Focus on using proper form and control rather than speed.

Name: Lever Alternate Biceps Curl
Description:
1. Start by positioning yourself on a seated lever machine, ensuring that your feet are flat on the ground and knees are slightly bent.

2. Grasp the lever handles with an underhand grip, making sure your palms are facing upwards. Your arms should be fully extended and hands aligned with your shoulders.

3. Keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and slowly curl the lever handles towards your shoulders, contracting your biceps. Make sure to maintain control throughout the movement.

4. While curling, focus on squeezing your biceps at the top of the contraction for a brief moment.

5. Inhale and slowly lower the lever handles back to the starting position, fully extending your arms without locking your elbows.

Remember to perform this exercise with proper form, engaging your biceps muscles and avoiding any jerky or swinging motions.

Name: Lever Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Sit down on a bench or seat with your back straight and your feet firmly planted on the ground, shoulder-width apart.

2. Grasp the handles of the lever machine with an overhand grip, keeping your elbows close to your body and your palms facing downwards.

3. Begin the movement by extending your arms fully, straightening them as you push the lever down. Make sure to keep your upper arms stationary throughout the exercise.

4. Pause momentarily when your arms are fully extended, feeling a stretch in your triceps.

5. Slowly bring the lever back up to the starting position by flexing your elbows while maintaining control of the movement.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on proper form and engaging your triceps throughout the entire range of motion.

Remember to consult a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercise to ensure proper technique and prevent injury.

Name: Lever Side Hip Abduction
Synergist: Adductor Brevis, Adductor Longus, Pectineous, Sartorius
Description:
1. Start by lying on your side on a mat or exercise mat, ensuring that your body is in a straight line.

2. Place your bottom arm out in front of you, palm resting on the mat for support.

3. Bend your top knee and place your foot flat on the mat in front of your bottom leg.

4. Engage your core and lift your top leg upward, while keeping it straight, until it is at hip height.

5. Hold the position at the top for a few seconds, feeling the contraction in your side hip muscles.

6. Slowly lower your leg back down to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

7. Repeat the exercise on the same side for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Name: Lever Side Hip Adduction
Description:
1. Sit comfortably on the lever side hip adduction machine, with your back against the pad and feet flat on the floor.

2. Adjust the lever arm so that it is positioned at the outer side of your leg, just above your ankle.

3. Engage your core and keep your upper body stable throughout the exercise.

4. Without moving any other part of your body, push your leg against the lever arm and bring it across your body towards your opposite leg.

5. Slowly release the pressure on the lever arm and return your leg to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise with the same leg for the desired number of repetitions, then switch to the other leg.

Remember to consult with a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercises, especially if you have any underlying medical conditions or injuries. It is important to perform exercises with proper form and technique to avoid any potential injuries.

Name: Lever Standing Leg Raise
Description:
1. 1) Begin by standing tall with your feet hip-width apart and your hands resting on a sturdy surface for balance, such as a chair or countertop.
2) Shift your weight onto your left leg, keeping a slight bend in your knee.
3) Slowly lift your right leg straight out in front of you, pointing your toes and engaging your core for stability. Keep your leg straight as you raise it as high as comfortably possible, ideally parallel to the ground.
4) Hold the lifted position for a brief moment, focusing on maintaining balance and engaging the muscles in your standing leg.
5) Lower your right leg back down to the starting position, ensuring that you keep control and maintain balance throughout the movement.
6) Switch sides and repeat the exercise with your left leg, lifting it straight out in front of you and holding the position before lowering it back down.

Remember to breathe throughout the exercise and focus on your form and balance.

Name: Lever Standing Rear Kick
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with your feet hip-width apart and your arms relaxed by your sides.

2. Lift your right leg off the ground and extend it straight behind you while leaning your upper body slightly forward.

3. At the same time, swing your right arm forward, keeping it straight and parallel to the ground.

4. Engage your core muscles for stability as you kick your right leg backward with a slight bend in the knee, aiming to bring your heel towards your glutes.

5. As you complete the kick, swing your right leg forward again and lower it back to the starting position with control.

6. Repeat the movement on the same leg for the desired number of repetitions before switching to the other leg.

Keep up the good work and enjoy your workout!

Name: Lever Chair Squat
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on a sturdy chair with your feet flat on the ground and hip-width apart.

2. Place your hands on the armrests or your thighs for support and stability.

3. Keep your back straight and engage your core muscles.

4. Slowly stand up from the chair, pushing through your heels and keeping your weight evenly distributed.

5. Extend your hips and knees fully, ensuring that you are not locking your joints.

6. Pause briefly at the top, then slowly lower yourself back down to the seated position by bending your hips and knees.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember to maintain a controlled movement throughout, focusing on using your leg muscles to lift your body weight. Be conscious of your form to avoid any excessive strain on your joints.

Name: Lever Full Squat
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and ensure that the lever bar is securely positioned across your upper back.

2. Engage your core muscles and maintain a straight back as you begin to lower your body down into a squatting position.

3. Bend your knees and hips simultaneously, making sure to keep your weight centered over your feet. Aim to achieve a 90-degree angle at your knees, with your thighs parallel to the ground.

4. As you descend, inhale and maintain a controlled and steady movement, keeping your chest lifted and your head facing forward.

5. Once you reach the bottom position of the squat, explosively push through your heels and extend your knees and hips, elevating your body back to the starting position.

6. Exhale as you reach the top of the movement, ensuring that your knees remain slightly flexed to avoid locking them out and placing unnecessary stress on the joints.

Name: Lever Pistol Squat
Description:
1. Find a sturdy platform or raised surface to use as a lever for support.

2. Stand facing away from the platform with your feet hip-width apart.

3. Extend one leg straight out in front of you, while gripping the platform/lever with both hands for support.

4. Slowly lower yourself into a squat position, keeping your standing leg bent and your other leg extended.

5. Pause for a moment at the bottom of the squat, ensuring your knee is directly above your ankle and maintaining a straight back.

6. Push through your heel to straighten your standing leg and return to the starting position, without letting your elevated foot touch the ground.

Name: Lever Lying Chest Press (plate loaded)
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by lying down on the lever lying chest press machine and adjust the seat and backrest to ensure a comfortable position.

2. Extend your arms straight out in front of you and grasp the handles of the machine, making sure your palms are facing downward.

3. Engage your core muscles and press the handles forward, pushing the weight plates away from your body until your arms are fully extended. Keep your elbows slightly bent throughout the movement.

4. Hold the extended position for a brief pause, focusing on contracting your chest muscles.

5. Slowly reverse the motion, inhaling as you bring the handles back towards your chest, allowing the weight plates to gently touch your body without bouncing.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining controlled and smooth movements throughout the exercise.

Name: Weighted Lying Neck Extension
Description:
1. Lie on your back on a flat surface such as a mat or a bench.

2. Place a weight plate or a weighted object on your forehead, holding it firmly in place with your hands.

3. Slowly lower your head backward towards the ground, maintaining control of the weight as you do so.

4. Extend your neck backwards as far as possible without experiencing any pain or discomfort.

5. Hold this position for a few seconds, feeling the stretch in your neck muscles.

6. Slowly return to the starting position by lifting your head back up, ensuring that you maintain control of the weight throughout the movement.

Remember to always start with a light load and gradually increase the weight as you become more comfortable and confident with the exercise. Make sure to maintain proper form and technique throughout to avoid any strain or injury.

Name: Weighted Lying Neck Flexion
Description:
1. Lie flat on your back on a comfortable surface, such as a yoga mat or exercise bench.

2. Place a weight or dumbbell on your forehead, ensuring that it is securely balanced and stable.

3. Keep your neck relaxed and in a neutral position, with your eyes facing upward towards the ceiling.

4. Slowly and steadily, engage your neck muscles and lift your head up towards your chest, using the weight to provide resistance and assistance.

5. Hold the lifted position for a few seconds, feeling a gentle stretch in the front of your neck.

6. Slowly lower your head back down to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Remember to consult a fitness professional or doctor before attempting any new exercise, especially if you have any pre-existing neck or spine conditions.

Name: Barbell Seated Military Press (inside squat cage)
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a bench inside a squat cage, with your back straight and feet firmly planted on the ground.

2. Grab the barbell with an overhand grip that is slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Lift the barbell up and position it just above your collarbone, resting on your upper chest and shoulders.

4. Take a deep breath, brace your core, and press the barbell straight up overhead, extending your arms fully.

5. Slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position, keeping your elbows slightly in front of you and your shoulder blades engaged.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Cable Elevated Row
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Stand facing a cable machine with a straight and tall posture.

2. Extend your arms and grab the handles attached to the cable machine, palms facing each other.

3. Take a step back to create tension on the cables and maintain a slight bend in your knees.

4. Pull your shoulder blades back and down, engaging the muscles in your upper back, and squeeze your shoulder blades together.

5. Slowly release the tension and return to the starting position, keeping your arms extended but relaxed.

Name: Cable Close-Grip Front Lat Pulldown
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Teres Major, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Sit facing the cable machine with your thighs secured under the thigh pads.

2. Grab the close-grip handles with both hands, palms facing inward.

3. Keep your back straight and pull the handles down towards your chest while engaging your back muscles.

4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement for an extra contraction.

5. Slowly allow the handles to return to the starting position while keeping your back straight and in control.

Remember to maintain proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Barbell Hip Thrust
Description:
1. Start by sitting on the floor with your upper back leaning against a low bench or step. Place a barbell right above your hips, and hold it firmly with a shoulder-width grip.

2. Roll the barbell towards your body, ensuring that it is directly above your hips. Keep your feet planted firmly on the ground, with your knees bent at a 90-degree angle.

3. Begin the movement by pushing your hips up towards the ceiling, while keeping your upper back and feet grounded. Focus on squeezing your glutes as you drive up.

4. As you reach the top of the movement, your body should form a straight line from your knees to your shoulders. Pause for a moment at the top, contracting your glutes before slowly lowering your hips back down to the starting position.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining control and steady breathing throughout.

Remember to start with a lighter weight to ensure proper form and gradually increase the load as you become more comfortable with the exercise.

Name: Burpee
Description:
1. Start in a standing position with your feet shoulder-width apart.

2. Lower your body into a squat position by bending your knees and bringing your hands down to the ground in front of your feet.

3. Kick your feet back into a push-up position while keeping your arms extended.

4. Immediately drop your chest to the ground and perform a push-up.

5. Push through your palms and spring your feet back towards your hands, returning to the squat position.

6. From the squat position, explosively jump into the air, reaching your hands overhead.

7. Land softly and repeat the exercise.

Name: Barbell Standing Military Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by placing a barbell on a squat rack at shoulder height. Position your feet shoulder-width apart and stand facing the barbell.

2. Reach up and grip the barbell with an overhand grip that is slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Position your hands so that your palms are facing forward and your elbows are pointing forward as well.

3. Lift the barbell off the rack by straightening your arms. Step back a few steps to clear the rack and position yourself with your feet firmly planted on the ground, your core engaged, and your back straight.

4. Bend your knees slightly and brace your core as you prepare to lift the barbell overhead. Inhale deeply, then exhale as you press the barbell directly upward in a straight line.

5. Continue to press the barbell upwards until your arms are fully extended, but be careful not to lock your elbows at the top of the movement. Maintain control throughout the exercise and keep your core engaged for stability.

6. Slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position, being mindful to maintain control and not let the weight drop. Inhale as you lower the barbell, then repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

(Note: Remember to always use proper form and start with lighter weights to ensure proper execution and minimize the risk of injury. If you are unsure about performing this exercise, it is recommended to seek guidance from a qualified fitness professional.)

Name: Lying Leg Raise
Synergist: Gluteus Maximus, Iliopsoas, Quadriceps, Sartorius, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Lie flat on your back on an exercise mat or the floor, with your arms resting by your sides.

2. Keep your legs together and fully extend them, with your toes pointing towards the ceiling.

3. Engage your core muscles by gently drawing your belly button in towards your spine.

4. Slowly lift your legs towards the ceiling, while keeping them straight and avoiding any swinging motion.

5. Continue to lift until your legs are perpendicular to the floor or as close as you can comfortably bring them.

6. Lower your legs back down slowly and with control, until they are hovering just above the ground.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions. Remember to maintain proper form and control throughout the movement.

Notes for the user: Make sure to breathe throughout the exercise and focus on using your abdominal muscles to lift your legs rather than relying on momentum. Keep your torso still and avoid arching your lower back. If you experience any discomfort or strain, modify the exercise or consult a fitness professional for guidance. Enjoy your workout!

Name: Smith Calf Raise (version 2)
Description:
1. Stand on a calf raise machine with your feet shoulder-width apart and your toes pointing forward.

2. Position your shoulders under the pads and engage your core for stability.

3. Slowly raise your heels as high as you can by pushing through the balls of your feet while keeping your knees straight.

4. Hold for a brief moment at the top of the movement, then slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position.

5. Focus on maintaining control throughout the exercise and avoid any jerking or sudden movements.

Name: Barbell Incline Wide Reverse-grip Bench Press
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by positioning yourself on an incline bench with your back leaning against the pad, feet flat on the floor, and your knees bent at a 90-degree angle.

2. Grip the barbell with an overhand grip that is slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, making sure your palms are facing towards you (reverse grip).

3. Lift the barbell off the rack, keeping your arms fully extended and elbows slightly bent. This is the starting position.

4. Slowly lower the barbell towards your upper chest, focusing on keeping your elbows pointed out to the sides and your upper arms parallel to the floor.

5. Once the barbell reaches your upper chest, pause for a brief moment, and then push it back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

6. Repeat steps 4 and 5 for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining control and proper form throughout the exercise.

Name: Dumbbell Incline Front Raise
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on an incline bench with your back against the pad and holding a dumbbell in each hand.

2. Start with your arms hanging down in front of you, palms facing your body.

3. Slowly lift both dumbbells simultaneously, while maintaining a slight bend in your elbows, until your arms are parallel to the ground.

4. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, squeezing your shoulder muscles.

5. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, with control.

Name: Dumbbell Lying Hammer Press (version 2)
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Lie down on a flat bench with your back supported and your feet firmly planted on the ground.

2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing each other, and extend your arms straight above your chest.

3. Slowly lower the dumbbells down towards the sides of your chest, keeping your elbows at a 90-degree angle.

4. Push the dumbbells back up to the starting position by extending your arms while maintaining control and a slight bend in your elbows.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form throughout the exercise.

Name: Flutter Kicks (version 2)
Description:
1. Lie flat on your back with your legs extended and your arms by your sides.

2. Lift both of your legs a few inches off the ground, ensuring that your lower back is pressed into the floor.

3. Begin the flutter kicks by alternating and quickly kicking your legs up and down in small, controlled motions.

4. Keep your legs straight and your toes pointed throughout the exercise.

5. Continue the flutter kicks for the desired duration or as instructed by a fitness professional.

Name: Incline Twisting Sit-up (version 2)
Synergist: Pectineous, Quadriceps, Rectus Abdominis, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Lie down on an incline bench with your feet secured at the bottom and your knees bent at a 90-degree angle.

2. Place your hands behind your head, interlocking your fingers, and keep your elbows out to the sides.

3. Slowly lift your upper body off the bench by engaging your abdominal muscles, and simultaneously twist your torso to one side.

4. Hold the position briefly, feeling the contraction in your oblique muscles on the side you twisted toward.

5. Lower your upper body back down to the starting position while keeping your core engaged, then repeat the movement to the opposite side.

6. Continue alternating sides, focusing on controlled and deliberate movements while maintaining proper form throughout the exercise.

Name: Lever Lying T-bar Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by positioning your body on a flat bench with your chest pressed against the surface.

2. Place the T-bar handle into the lever arm, ensuring that it is securely fastened.

3. Grasp the handle with an overhand grip and extend your arms fully, keeping them perpendicular to the floor.

4. Begin the exercise by retracting your shoulder blades and pulling the handle towards your chest in a rowing motion.

5. Pause for a moment when the handle is in line with your chest, then slowly return to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

6. Repeat the rowing motion for your desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Lever Incline Hammer Chest Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by sitting on the incline bench, with your feet firmly planted on the ground and your back pressed against the bench.

2. Grasp the handles of the lever machine, positioning your hands shoulder-width apart, with your palms facing forward.

3. Inhale and gradually push the handles away from your body, extending your arms fully in front of you. Keep your elbows slightly bent to maintain tension in your chest muscles.

4. Exhale and slowly bring the handles back towards your body, while maintaining control and not allowing the weights to slam together at the end of the movement.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

6. Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, keeping your core engaged and your back against the bench.

Name: Dumbbell Alternate Biceps Curl
Description:
1. Begin by standing up straight with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing inward towards your body.

2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and exhale as you curl one dumbbell up towards your shoulder, making sure to keep your upper arm stationary.

3. Continue the motion while inhaling and lower the dumbbell back down to the starting position in a controlled manner.

4. Repeat the previous step with the opposite arm, completing one full repetition.

5. Alternate between each arm, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement.

6. Continue alternating curls for the desired number of reps or as instructed by your fitness professional.

Remember to start with a weight that you can comfortably handle and gradually increase the weight as you gain strength and proficiency in the exercise. Regularly perform this exercise as part of your biceps training routine to effectively target and strengthen your bicep muscles.

Name: Squat (male)
Description:
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointed slightly outward.

2. Engage your core and keep your back straight as you begin to lower your body by bending at the knees and hips.

3. Continue lowering until your thighs are parallel to the ground, or as close as possible without feeling any discomfort or pain.

4. Pause for a second in the lowered position, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form throughout the exercise.

Remember to consult a fitness professional or doctor before starting any new exercise program, especially if you have any pre-existing medical conditions or injuries.

Name: Cable horizontal Pallof Press
Description:
1. Stand perpendicular to a cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent.

2. Grip the cable handle with both hands and hold it at chest level, extending your arms straight out in front of you.

3. Brace your core and engage your glutes to maintain a stable stance.

4. Slowly and under control, push the cable handle away from your chest while maintaining a straight line from your hands to your torso.

5. Hold the fully extended position for a few seconds, focusing on keeping your core tight and resisting any rotation or movement.

6. Slowly return the cable handle back to your chest, maintaining control throughout the movement.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember, it's important to start with an appropriate weight and focus on proper form to get the most out of this exercise.

Name: Cable one arm inner biceps curl
Description:
1. Stand facing a cable machine with a wide grip attachment at waist level.

2. Grab the handle with one hand, palm facing up, and step away from the machine to create tension on the cable.

3. Keep your upper arm stationary and exhale as you curl the handle towards your shoulder, contracting the bicep muscles.

4. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement and squeeze your biceps.

5. Inhale as you slowly lower the handle back to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the exercise.

Remember to switch sides and perform the same steps with your other arm to ensure balanced muscle development. Focus on maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise for optimal results.

Name: Cable pull through
Description:
1. Begin by standing facing away from the cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. Grab the handle or attachment of the cable machine with both hands and step forward until there is some tension in the cable.

2. Hinge at your hips, keeping your back straight and core engaged, and push your hips back as you lower your upper body towards the ground. Your knees should have a slight bend throughout the movement.

3. Brace your core and maintain a neutral spine as you push through your hips, driving them forward as you stand up tall. As you do this, keep your arms extended and pull the cable between your legs, squeezing your glutes at the top of the movement.

4. Slowly reverse the movement and hinge at your hips again, lowering your upper body towards the ground and allowing the cable to pull you back. Keep your back straight and your core engaged throughout the exercise.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and feeling the tension in your glutes and hamstrings as you drive your hips forward and squeeze your glutes at the top of each repetition.

Remember to always consult with a fitness professional before attempting any new exercise to ensure proper form and technique. Enjoy your workout and challenge yourself!

Name: Cable vertical Pallof Press
Description:
1. Stand perpendicular to a cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart and a slight bend in your knees.

2. Grasp the cable handle with both hands and bring it to your chest, keeping your elbows at a 90-degree angle.

3. Engage your core and keep your back straight as you begin to press the cable directly out in front of you, fully extending your arms.

4. Hold this position for a few seconds, focusing on keeping your body stable and resisting any rotation or movement caused by the cable.

5. Slowly and controlled, return the cable handle back to your chest, maintaining your balance and core engagement throughout the movement. 

Remember to start with a manageable weight and gradually increase as you become comfortable with the exercise.

Name: Dumbbell Incline reverse-grip 30 degrees bench press
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Lie down on an incline bench set at a 30-degree angle.

2. Hold a pair of dumbbells with a reverse (underhand) grip, keeping your palms facing towards your body.

3. Start with the dumbbells positioned slightly above your upper chest, arms extended, and elbows slightly bent.

4. Slowly lower the dumbbells towards your chest in a controlled manner, while keeping your elbows tucked in.

5. Pause for a brief moment when the dumbbells reach your chest, then press them back up to the starting position, exhaling as you extend your arms.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, making sure to maintain proper form throughout the exercise.

Name: Lever seated one leg calf raise
Description:
1. Sit on a lever seated calf raise machine with your knees bent at a 90-degree angle and your feet placed on the footrest.

2. Position one foot in the center of the footrest, ensuring that your toes are pointing forward and your heel is slightly hanging off the edge.

3. Slowly press down with your foot, extending your ankle as much as possible while keeping your knee stationary. This is the starting position.

4. Begin raising your heel by lifting your toes towards the ceiling, using only the muscles in your calf. Continue until you feel a stretch in your calf muscles.

5. Hold the raised position for a moment, then slowly lower your heel back down to the starting position.

6. Repeat the same steps for the desired number of repetitions before switching to the other leg.

Remember to always engage in a proper warm-up before starting any exercise and consult with a fitness professional if you have any concerns or questions about the exercise.

Name: Lever Calf Raise (bench press machine)
Description:
1. Sit on the calf raise machine with your knees pressed against the pads and your feet resting on the lower platform.

2. Adjust the height of the bench press machine so that your shoulders are in line with the lever pads.

3. Grasp the handles on the sides of the machine for stability and keep your body upright throughout the exercise.

4. Slowly push the lever upward by extending your ankles, raising your heels as high as possible.

5. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, ensuring you feel the stretch in your calves.

6. Slowly lower the lever back down by flexing your ankles, bringing your heels towards the ground.
 
Remember to maintain proper form and control throughout the exercise to effectively target your calf muscles.

Name: Lever Shrug (bench press machine)
Description:
1. First, sit on the bench press machine and place your feet flat on the ground.

2. Grasp the handles of the machine, ensuring that your palms are facing downwards and your grip is secure.

3. Engage your core muscles and keep your back straight throughout the exercise.

4. Slowly lift the handles upward by extending your arms, keeping your elbows slightly bent.

5. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement, ensuring that you feel the contraction in your upper back.

6. Lower the handles back down slowly to the starting position, maintaining control and a steady pace.

Remember to adjust the weight according to your strength and abilities. It's important to perform each rep with proper form to maximize the benefits of this exercise.

Name: Underhand-Grip Inverted Back Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Find a low bar or a Smith machine, and set it at a height where you can hang from it with your arms fully extended.

2. Grab the bar with an underhand grip, with your palms facing up and hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Hang from the bar, fully extending your arms and allowing your body to hang freely below.

4. Keeping your core engaged, pull your chest up towards the bar by retracting your shoulder blades and bending your elbows. Focus on using your back muscles to initiate the movement.

5. Continue pulling until your chest reaches the bar and squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top.

6. Slowly lower yourself back to the starting position with control, fully extending your arms and keeping your back engaged.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, breathe regularly, and use a weight or resistance that challenges you but still allows for controlled movements. Good luck with your workout!

Name: Dumbbell Standing Inner Biceps Curl
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing forward.

2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and exhale as you curl the dumbbells upward, rotating your palms inward as you lift.

3. Continue to raise the dumbbells until they reach shoulder level, ensuring that only your forearms are moving.

4. Hold the contracted position for a second, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.

5. Inhale as you slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, with your arms fully extended and your palms facing forward.

6. Repeat steps 2 to 5 for the recommended number of repetitions.

Name: Lever Seated Squat
Description:
1. Start by sitting on the lever seated squat machine with your back firmly against the backrest and your feet shoulder-width apart on the footplate.

2. Engage your core and firmly grip the handles on both sides of the seat. This will help you maintain stability throughout the exercise.

3. Begin the movement by pushing through your heels and extending your legs to lift the weight. Keep your back straight and maintain a slow and controlled motion.

4. Once you have fully extended your legs, pause for a moment and squeeze your quadriceps muscles at the top of the movement.

5. Slowly lower the weight by bending your knees and hips, ensuring that you maintain control and do not let the weight drop too quickly.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on the mind-muscle connection and maintaining proper form throughout.

Remember to consult with a fitness professional or trainer before performing any new exercise to ensure proper technique and prevent injury.

Name: Dumbbell One Arm Row (rack support)
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Begin by placing a dumbbell on the floor next to a weight rack.

2. Stand next to the weight rack and position your feet shoulder-width apart.

3. Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips, keeping your back straight. Rest your non-working hand on the weight rack for support.

4. With your working hand, grip the dumbbell handle and lift it off the floor, using your back muscles to maintain stability and control.

5. Once the dumbbell is lifted, exhale and pull your working arm upward in a rowing motion, keeping your elbow close to your body. Focus on squeezing your back muscles as you lift the weight.

6. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the dumbbell back to the starting position, keeping your back straight and core engaged throughout the exercise.

Remember to perform the exercise with proper form and control, and consult a fitness professional if you have any concerns or questions about your technique.

Name: Lever Row (plate loaded)
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Begin by adjusting the seat height and foot placement on the lever row machine to ensure a stable and comfortable position.

2. Position yourself facing the lever row machine and grab the handles with a comfortable overhand grip, ensuring that your arms are fully extended in front of you.

3. With a straight back and core engaged, pull the handles towards your torso by retracting your shoulder blades, while keeping your elbows close to your body.

4. Pause for a moment when the handles touch your torso, squeezing your back muscles at the top of the movement.

5. Slowly release and extend your arms back to the starting position, maintaining control and avoiding any jerking or swinging motions.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and engaging your back muscles throughout the movement.

Name: Cable Seated Row (Bent bar)
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Sit on the seat of the cable machine with your feet flat on the floor and knees slightly bent. Adjust the footrest to a comfortable height.

2. Grab the bent bar attachment with an overhand grip, placing your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Keeping your back straight and chest lifted, exhale and pull the bar towards your torso by squeezing your shoulder blades together. Focus on using your back muscles to initiate the movement rather than your arms.

4. Pause for a moment when the bar reaches your lower chest, squeezing your back muscles tightly.

5. Inhale and slowly release the bar back to the starting position, ensuring a controlled and smooth movement.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form throughout the entire set.

Remember to start with a weight that allows you to perform the exercise with correct form and gradually increase the resistance as you become more comfortable and stronger.

Name: Flutter Kicks (version 3)
Synergist: Adductor Brevis, Adductor Longus, Pectineous, Quadriceps, Sartorius, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Lie flat on your back on the floor or exercise mat.

2. Extend your legs fully, keeping them together.

3. Place your arms on either side of your body, palms facing down.

4. Lift both of your legs a few inches off the ground, keeping them straight.

5. Begin the exercise by rapidly alternating between raising one leg while lowering the other, similar to a scissor motion.

6. Focus on engaging your core and keeping your lower back pressed into the mat throughout the exercise.

Name: Lying Leg Raise and Hold
Description:
1. Begin by lying flat on your back on a comfortable mat or exercise surface. Make sure your legs are fully extended and your arms are relaxed by your sides.

2. Engage your core muscles by drawing your navel towards your spine. This will help stabilize your lower back during the exercise.

3. Slowly lift both legs off the ground, keeping them straight and together. Focus on using your abdominal muscles to control the movement and avoid any swinging or jerking motions.

4. Raise your legs until they are perpendicular to the floor or as high as you can comfortably go. You should feel a gentle tension in your lower abdominal area.

5. Hold this position for a few seconds, making sure to keep your core muscles engaged and your lower back pressed firmly against the mat.

6. Slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position, maintaining control and keeping them as straight as possible. Take a brief rest before repeating the exercise if desired.

Remember to listen to your body and only perform exercises that are suitable for your fitness level. If you experience any pain or discomfort during the exercise, it's important to stop and consult with a healthcare professional.

Name: Russian Twist (with medicine ball)
Description:
1. Sit down on the floor with your knees slightly bent and your feet flat on the ground.

2. Hold a medicine ball in both hands and extend your arms straight in front of your chest, keeping your back straight and your core engaged.

3. Slowly twist your torso to the right side, keeping your hips and lower body stable. Your arms and the medicine ball should move together as you rotate.

4. Continue the twist until the medicine ball touches the ground on the right side of your body, then pause for a moment.

5. Reverse the movement and twist your torso to the left side, bringing the medicine ball to touch the ground on the left side of your body.

6. Continue alternating the twists from side to side, keeping your core engaged and maintaining control throughout the entire movement.

Remember to start with a lighter medicine ball and gradually increase the weight as your strength improves. Also, breathe consistently throughout the exercise and avoid using momentum to swing the medicine ball. Keep your movements slow and controlled to maximize the effectiveness of the exercise.

Name: Half Wipers (bent leg)
Description:
1. Lie flat on your back with your arms extended out to the sides and palms facing down.

2. Bend your knees and bring your feet up off the ground, so that your lower legs are parallel to the floor.

3. Keeping your knees bent, slowly lower both legs down to one side towards the ground, as far as you can comfortably go while maintaining control.

4. Once you've reached your maximum range of motion, slowly bring your legs back up to the starting position, keeping them bent the entire time.

5. Repeat the movement, this time lowering your legs down to the opposite side, and return them back up to the starting position.

6. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps or duration of your workout.

Name: Wipers (straight leg)
Description:
1. Lie flat on your back on a mat or exercise bench.

2. Extend your legs straight up toward the ceiling, keeping them together and perpendicular to the ground.

3. Keeping your legs straight and together, slowly lower them to one side, aiming to touch the ground with your feet.

4. Without pausing, lift your legs back up to the starting position.

5. Repeat the movement, this time lowering your legs to the opposite side.

6. Continue alternating sides, completing the prescribed number of repetitions.

Remember to engage your core muscles throughout the exercise to maintain stability and control.

Name: Lever Donkey Calf Raise
Description:
1. Stand in front of a lever calf raise machine, placing your feet on the foot platform with your toes pointing forward.

2. Adjust the machine so that the shoulder pads rest comfortably on your upper thighs, just above the knee joint.

3. Engage your core and grip the handles on the sides of the machine for stability.

4. With control, raise your heels by extending your ankles, lifting your body up on your toes as high as possible.

5. Hold the top position for a second, focusing on squeezing your calf muscles.

6. Slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position, feeling a stretch in your calves.

Name: Barbell Decline Pullover
Synergist: Deltoid Posterior, Latissimus Dorsi, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Teres Major
Description:
1. Lie down on a decline bench with your head at the lower end, making sure your feet are secured under the provided pads.

2. Grasp a barbell with an overhand grip (hands placed shoulder-width apart) and hold it directly above your chest, arms extended.

3. Keeping a slight bend in your elbows, slowly lower the barbell behind your head in an arc-like motion until you feel a stretch in your chest and shoulders. Make sure to maintain control throughout the movement.

4. Pause for a moment at the stretched position and then slowly raise the barbell back to the starting position, using the same arc-like motion.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember, it is important to use proper form and start with a weight that allows you to perform the exercise safely and effectively. If you have any concerns or questions, it's always a good idea to consult with a fitness professional before attempting a new exercise routine.

Name: Barbell Reverse Grip Decline Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Lie down on a decline bench with your head positioned lower than your feet. Grip the barbell with a reverse grip, meaning your palms are facing towards your face.

2. Ensure your hands are shoulder-width apart and your thumbs are wrapped around the bar. Your arms should be fully extended and perpendicular to the floor.

3. Using your chest and triceps muscles, slowly lower the bar towards your lower chest by bending your elbows.

4. Pause for a moment when the bar touches your chest and then exhale as you push the barbell back up to the starting position. Ensure that your elbows are fully extended at the top of the movement.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired amount of repetitions, focusing on maintaining control and proper form throughout.

Remember to always warm up before performing any exercise and consult with a fitness professional if you're new to this exercise or have any concerns.

Name: Barbell Reverse Grip Incline Bench Press
Description:
1. Start by adjusting the incline bench to a 30 to 45-degree angle.

2. Lay down on the bench with your back flat and feet planted firmly on the ground.

3. Grasp the barbell with a reverse grip (palms facing towards you) at a slightly wider than shoulder-width distance.

4. Inhale and lower the barbell slowly towards your upper chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle to your body.

5. Exhale and push the barbell up using your chest and triceps until your arms are fully extended but without locking out your elbows.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, engage your core muscles, and start with a weight that challenges you but allows you to maintain control and proper technique.

Name: Barbell Wide Reverse Grip Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by lying flat on a bench with your feet firmly planted on the floor.

2. Grasp the barbell with a wide overhand grip, with your palms facing towards your body.

3. Slowly lower the barbell down towards your chest, keeping your elbows tucked in close to your body.

4. Pause for a brief moment when the barbell is just above your chest, then push the barbell back up to the starting position by extending your arms.

5. Ensure that you keep a controlled movement throughout the exercise, engaging your chest, shoulders, and triceps.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and engaging the targeted muscles.

Remember to always consult with a fitness professional to ensure proper form and avoid any injuries while performing this exercise.

Name: Cable Decline Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Adjust the cable machine: Set the pulleys at the lowest position and attach the handles to each side of the cables.

2. Position yourself: Stand facing away from the cable machine and position your feet hip-width apart. Take a step forward with one foot, while keeping a slight bend in your knees.

3. Grasp the handles: Reach back and grasp the handles with an overhand grip. Your palms should be facing downward, and your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

4. Engage your core: Brace your core muscles by drawing your belly button in towards your spine. This will provide stability throughout the exercise.

5. Perform the press: Begin by bending your elbows and bringing your hands towards your upper chest, keeping your upper arms parallel to the floor. Press the handles forward by extending your arms fully, but do not lock out your elbows.

6. Return to starting position: Slowly reverse the movement and bring the handles back to the initial position, controlling the resistance as you release. Pause briefly at the starting position before starting the next repetition.

Name: Cable Standing Up Straight Crossovers
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head
Description:
1. Stand in front of a cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart, and adjust the pulley to the lowest position.

2. Hold the cable handle with one hand, palm facing down, and stand far enough from the pulley for tension on the cable.

3. Keeping your arm straight, begin by raising your hand diagonally across your body until it reaches the opposite shoulder, crossing in front of your torso.

4. Slowly lower your hand back to the starting position, maintaining control and tension on the cable throughout the movement.

5. Repeat the above steps, alternating hands for each repetition.

(Note: It is important to brace your core, keep your back straight, and avoid using excessive momentum during the exercise.)

Name: Cable Upper Chest Crossovers
Description:
1. Begin by setting the cable pulleys at the highest position on both sides of the cable machine.
