2. Stand in the center of the machine, with one foot slightly in front of the other for stability.

3. Grab one handle with each hand, ensuring that your palms are facing downward and your arms are slightly bent.

4. Slowly pull the handles downward and inward in a controlled motion, crossing them in front of your body.

5. Pause for a moment once your hands meet in the center of your chest, squeezing your chest muscles.

6. Slowly release the tension and allow your arms to return to the starting position.

7. Repeat steps 4-6 for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Lever Incline Chest Press
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on the incline chest press machine with your feet placed firmly on the ground.

2. Grasp the handles of the machine with an overhand grip, positioning your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Press the handles forward and straighten your arms, pushing the weight away from your body. Keep your back straight and engage your core muscles.

4. Slowly lower the handles back towards your chest, maintaining control over the weight as you descend. Keep your elbows slightly bent throughout the movement to avoid locking them.

5. Once you have reached the starting position, repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on contracting your chest muscles while controlling the weight.

Remember to always consult with a certified fitness professional before attempting any new exercises to ensure proper form and technique.

Name: Lever Decline Chest Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by adjusting the seat of the lever decline chest press machine to a suitable height that allows your elbows to be slightly below shoulder level when seated.

2. Sit down on the machine with your back pressed firmly against the backrest and your feet flat on the floor.

3. Grasp the handles of the machine with an overhand grip, making sure that your hands are evenly spaced apart.

4. Keeping your core engaged and your back against the backrest, exhale and push the handles forward until your arms are almost fully extended.

5. In a controlled manner, inhale as you slowly bring the handles back towards your body, bending your elbows and allowing the weight to lower until your upper arms are parallel with the floor.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions while maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement.

Remember to consult with a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercise to ensure proper form and minimize the risk of injury.

Name: Machine Inner Chest Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Sit on the chest press machine and adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level.

3. Inhale and push the handles straight forward until your arms are fully extended, but without locking out your elbows.

4. Pause for a brief moment, focusing on squeezing your chest muscles, then exhale as you slowly retract your arms, bringing the handles back to the starting position.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring that you maintain control and proper form throughout the exercise.

Name: Smith Wide Grip Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by lying on the bench with your back flat and your feet planted firmly on the ground.

4. Slowly lower the bar towards your chest, bending your elbows at a 90-degree angle, while maintaining control and stability throughout the movement.

5. Push the barbell back up towards the starting position, fully extending your arms without locking out your elbows.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout.

Name: Smith Wide Grip Decline Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii

5. Push the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms without locking your elbows.

Remember, it is always recommended to consult with a fitness professional before attempting any new exercise, especially if you are unfamiliar with proper form or have any underlying health concerns.

Name: Wide Hand Push up
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by positioning yourself in a high plank position. Place your hands wider than shoulder-width apart, with your fingers pointing forward and your arms fully extended.

3. Slowly lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows, ensuring that your chest is in line with your hands. By keeping your elbows pointed outwards, you will specifically target your chest muscles during the exercise.

4. Pause for a moment when your chest is hovering just above the ground, making sure to maintain a straight body position and not allowing your hips to sag.

5. Straighten your arms to push your body back up to the starting position, while exhaling. Focus on pushing through your chest and shoulders to activate these muscles.

6. Repeat the above steps for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring proper form is maintained throughout the exercise.

Name: Lever Unilateral Row

Description:

5. Exhale as you use your chest and lats to pull the barbell back to its starting position above your chest, keeping your arms slightly bent throughout the movement.

Name: Barbell Reverse Grip Incline Bench Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Lie face down on an incline bench set at a 45-degree angle, with your chest resting against the pad and your feet firmly on the floor.

2. Grab the barbell with an underhand grip, placing your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Your palms should be facing up towards your chin.

3. Keep your body straight and pull the barbell up towards your chest, leading with your elbows. Aim to bring the barbell just below your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.

4. Pause for a moment at the top, feeling the contraction in your back muscles, then slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Remember to always consult with a professional or a trainer before attempting any new exercise, especially if you have any pre-existing conditions or injuries.

Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers

Name: Cable Rope Seated Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout each repetition.

Name: Chin-Up
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Teres Major, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers

Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Teres Major, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers

3. While maintaining control, pull yourself up towards the bar by bending your elbows, with your focus on using your back muscles rather than relying solely on your arms.

Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers

1. Lie face down on an incline bench set to a 45-degree angle, with a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your feet firmly on the floor and extend your arms fully towards the ground, palms facing inward.

2. Begin the movement by retracting your shoulder blades and lifting the dumbbells up towards the ceiling. Keep your elbows slightly bent and your hands in line with your shoulders.

3. While maintaining control, continue to lift the dumbbells until your arms are parallel to the floor and your shoulder blades are squeezed together. This is the starting position.

4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down towards the floor in a controlled manner, maintaining tension in your rear deltoids throughout the movement.

5. Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement, then repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember to engage your core for stability and focus on maintaining proper form throughout the exercise.

2. Hinge forward at the hips, keeping your back straight and parallel to the floor. Bend your knees slightly for balance.

3. While maintaining this bent-over position, engage your core and squeeze your shoulder blades together as you raise the dumbbells up towards your chest, leading with your elbows.

4. As you lift the dumbbells, rotate your wrists so that your palms are facing your body at the top of the movement.

5. Pause for a brief moment at the top while squeezing your back muscles, then slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, rotating your palms back to the starting position as well.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, focusing on maintaining proper form throughout the exercise.

Remember to consult with a professional trainer or fitness expert before attempting any new exercises to ensure proper technique and prevent injury.

Name: Dumbbell Reverse Grip Incline Bench Two Arm Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers

3. Engage your core and keep your back straight as you lift the dumbbells off the floor and bring them up to the sides of your chest, while squeezing your shoulder blades together.

4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, ensuring that your arms are fully extended, but not locked, at the bottom of the movement.

Name: Smith Bent Over Row

Name: Smith Reverse Grip Bent Over Row
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head

1. To start the Smith Reverse Grip Bent Over Row, position yourself in front of a Smith Machine with your feet shoulder-width apart.

2. Reach up and grab the pull-up bar with an overhand grip, ensuring that your palms are facing away from your body. Your hands should be positioned wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Engage your core and squeeze your shoulder blades together as you slowly pull your body upwards towards the bar. Focus on using the muscles in your back and arms to initiate the movement. Keep your elbows in line with your shoulders throughout the exercise.

4. Continue pulling yourself up until your chin is above the level of the bar, with your elbows pointing downwards and your chest close to the bar. Hold this contracted position for a brief pause, making sure to keep your body stable.

5. In a controlled manner, lower your body back down to the starting position while maintaining tension in your back and arms. Keep your core engaged and your shoulder blades squeezed together to maximize the effectiveness of the exercise.

Remember to consult with a fitness professional before attempting any new exercise, especially if you have any pre-existing injuries or medical conditions. Focus on maintaining proper form and breathing throughout the exercise for optimal results. Good luck with your wide grip rear pull-ups!

1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, placing a barbell across the front of your shoulders and upper chest.

2. Position the balls of your feet on a weight plate or a stable elevated surface, ensuring your heels are hanging off the edge.

3. Slowly raise your heels by extending your ankles, lifting your body upward as high as possible.

4. Hold the contracted position for a second, focusing on squeezing your calf muscles.

5. Slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position, allowing your calves to stretch.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, keeping control throughout the exercise.

Name: Bodyweight Standing Calf Raise
Description:
1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, keeping your core engaged and your shoulders relaxed.

2. Lift your heels off the ground, shifting your weight onto the balls of your feet.

3. Slowly raise your heels as high as possible without losing balance, while maintaining a neutral spine.

4. Pause for a brief moment at the top of the movement, focusing on contracting your calf muscles.

5. Lower your heels back down to the starting position, ensuring a controlled movement.

6. Repeat the exercise according to your desired number of repetitions or the instructions provided by your trainer.

Remember to always perform the exercise with proper form and start with a weight or difficulty level that is appropriate for your fitness level.

Name: Cable Standing Calf Raise
Description:
1. Attach a cable to a cable machine at the lowest setting and adjust the weight according to your fitness level.

2. Stand facing the cable machine with your feet hip-width apart and your toes pointing forward.

3. Hold onto the cable handles or the bar attachment with a firm grip and ensure that your shoulders are relaxed.

4. Slowly rise up onto the balls of your feet, lifting your heels off the ground.

5. Hold the raised position for a brief moment, feeling the stretch in your calf muscles.

6. Lower your heels back down to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Remember to focus on engaging your calf muscles and avoid using momentum to complete the exercise. Start with a weight that allows you to perform the exercise with proper form, gradually increasing the resistance as you become stronger. Enjoy your workout!

Name: Hack Calf Raise
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and parallel to each other.

2. Slowly lift your heels off the ground while maintaining balance and keeping your body straight.

3. As you rise up onto your toes, engage your calf muscles and squeeze them.

4. Hold the raised position for a couple of seconds, focusing on feeling the contraction in your calves.

5. Slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position, maintaining control and balance.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, following a controlled and smooth motion.

Name: Sled Calf Press On Leg Press
Description:
1. Sit in a leg press machine with your back comfortably against the backrest and your feet on the footplate at hip-width apart.

2. Place the sled attachment (a weighted platform) on top of your feet, with your toes pointed slightly upward and your heels on the sled.

3. Press the sled away from your body by straightening your knees while keeping your feet flexed, keeping your core engaged and your back against the backrest. This is the starting position.

4. Slowly bend your knees to lower the sled back towards your body, allowing your calves to stretch. Keep your heels on the sled and maintain control throughout the movement.

5. Once your calves are fully stretched, push the sled away from your body again by extending your knees with control. This completes one repetition.

6. Continue to perform the calf press by repeating steps 4 and 5 for the desired number of repetitions.

Note: As a final user executing this exercise, it is important to focus on maintaining proper form throughout, including keeping your core engaged, back against the backrest, and controlling the movement to avoid any rapid or jerking motions.

Name: Smith Reverse Calf Raises
Description:
1. Position yourself under the Smith machine so that the barbell is resting on your upper back.

2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart with your toes pointing forward.

3. Slowly raise your heels off the ground by extending your ankles as high as possible.

4. Hold the fully contracted position for a brief moment, ensuring your balance is maintained.

5. Lower your heels back down to the starting position, feeling a slight stretch in your calves.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Smith Toe Raise
Description:
1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and place a Smith machine barbell across your shoulders, resting it slightly below your neck.

2. Keep your core engaged and maintain a straight posture throughout the exercise.

3. Slowly raise your heels off the ground as high as possible while keeping the balls of your feet planted on the floor.

4. Hold the raised position for a brief moment to feel the contraction in your calf muscles.

5. Lower your heels back down to the starting position in a controlled manner.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Dumbbell One Arm Seated Neutral Wrist Curl
Description:
1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor and your back straight.

2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand with a neutral grip (palms facing inward) and rest your forearm on your thigh.

3. Slowly lower the dumbbell towards the floor by flexing your wrist, keeping your forearm stationary.

4. Pause for a moment when your wrist is fully flexed, feeling the stretch in your forearm.

5. Slowly raise the dumbbell back to the starting position by extending your wrist, while keeping your forearm stationary.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember to start with a weight that is suitable for your fitness level and gradually increase it as you get stronger. Always maintain proper form and listen to your body to avoid any injuries.

Name: Reverse Hyper on Flat Bench
Description:
1. Lie face down on a flat bench with your hips positioned at the edge of the bench.

2. Place your legs straight out behind you and grip the edges of the bench for stability.

3. Slowly raise your legs upward in a controlled motion until they are parallel to the floor or slightly above.

4. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, making sure to keep your core engaged.

5. Lower your legs back down to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the descent.

Name: Smith Seated Wrist Curl
Description:
1. Sit down on a bench or chair with your feet planted firmly on the ground.

2. Position yourself in front of a Smith machine, ensuring that the bar is at a height where you can comfortably reach it while sitting.

3. Grasp the bar with an underhand grip, with your palms facing upwards. Your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

4. Lower your wrists, allowing the bar to roll down towards your fingertips while keeping your forearms flat on your thighs.

5. Once your wrists are fully flexed and the bar is close to your fingertips, slowly curl your wrists back up towards your forearms, using the strength of your forearm muscles. Focus on squeezing your wrists and forearms throughout the movement.

6. Repeat the exercise for the recommended number of repetitions, keeping your movements controlled and avoiding any jerking motions.

Remember to consult with a fitness professional or instructor before attempting any new exercise to ensure proper form and technique.

Name: Wide Grip Pull-Up
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Teres Major, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Step up to the pull-up bar and grab it with a wide grip, placing your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Hang from the bar with your arms fully extended and your shoulders relaxed.

3. Engage your core muscles and squeeze your shoulder blades together as you pull your body up towards the bar.

4. Continue pulling until your chin is above the bar, with your elbows bending and pointing out to the sides.

5. Lower your body back down in a controlled manner to the starting position, fully extending your arms and relaxing your shoulders again.

6. Rest briefly before repeating the exercise.

Name: Smith Front Squat (Clean Grip)
Description:
1. Start by standing in front of the Smith machine with your feet about shoulder-width apart.

2. Position the barbell across your upper chest and shoulders, gripping it with a clean grip, where your palms are facing upwards and your elbows are pointing forward.

3. Engage your core and keep your back straight as you begin to squat down by bending your knees and pushing your hips backward.

4. Lower your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground or slightly below, making sure to keep your knees in line with your toes.

5. Drive through your heels and push upwards to return to the starting position, fully extending your legs and maintaining an upright posture.

6. Repeat the squatting movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Smith Low Bar Squat
Description:
1. Begin by positioning yourself under the Smith machine bar, setting the bar height to align with your chest level.

2. Step forward and place your feet shoulder-width apart, with your toes slightly pointing outward.

3. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, resting it on your upper traps and rear deltoids.

4. With a straight back and your core engaged, slowly lower your body by bending at the hips and knees, while maintaining a strong and stable stance.

5. Continue to descend until your thighs are parallel to the floor or slightly below, ensuring your knees do not extend past your toes.

6. Push through your heels and drive your hips forward to return to the starting position, maintaining control and tension throughout the movement.

Name: Barbell Low Bar Squat
Description:
1. Begin by positioning the barbell at a lower height on the squat rack, allowing it to rest across the back of your shoulders.

2. Stand facing the barbell with your feet shoulder-width apart. Take a step forward and place your feet slightly wider than hip-width apart, pointing your toes slightly outward.

3. Lower yourself into a squat position by bending at the knees and hips, keeping your back straight and chest up. The barbell should be resting on the back of your shoulders throughout the movement.

4. Lower yourself until your thighs are parallel to the ground, ensuring that your knees do not extend past your toes. It's important to keep your weight on your heels to maintain balance and stability.

5. Push up through your heels to return to the starting position, extending your hips and knees to stand tall. Repeat the exercise for your desired number of repetitions.

Name: Barbell High Bar Squat
Description:
1. Begin by setting up a barbell on a squat rack at an appropriate height. Make sure the bar is positioned slightly below shoulder level.

2. Stand facing the bar with your feet hip-width apart. Step forward and position yourself under the bar, ensuring it is resting on your upper traps and shoulders, just below the base of your neck.

3. Grip the barbell firmly with both hands, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Keep your elbows pointing down and tucked in, while maintaining a tight grip on the bar.

4. Take a deep breath and brace your core. Begin to descend by bending at the knees and hips, as if you are sitting back into an imaginary chair. Lower yourself until your thighs are parallel to the ground, ensuring your knees do not extend beyond your toes.

5. Pause briefly at the bottom, maintaining tension in your muscles, and then push through your heels to drive yourself back up to the starting position. Straighten your legs and fully extend your hips, while keeping your chest lifted and your back straight.

Name: Dumbbell finger curls
Description:
1. Sit on a flat surface with your back straight and legs bent at a 90-degree angle.

2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand, resting the weights on your thighs with your palms facing upward.

3. Slowly curl your fingers around the dumbbells, maintaining a firm grip, and lift the weights off your thighs.

4. With controlled movements, curl your fingers, bringing the dumbbells toward your palm. Keep your wrists straight throughout the exercise.

5. Once the dumbbells are lifted as high as possible, pause for a brief moment at the top of the movement.

6. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position by gradually opening your fingers, allowing the weights to rest on your thighs.

Remember to start with a weight that allows you to execute the exercise with proper form and gradually increase the weight as you gain strength.

Name: Lever Gripless Shrug (VERSION 2)
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent.

2. Extend your arms straight down in front of your body, with your palms facing inwards towards your thighs.

3. Keeping your arms straight, raise your shoulders up towards your ears as high as possible, while maintaining a gripless position, meaning your palms should not hold any weight or resistance.

4. Hold the elevated position for a brief moment, focusing on contracting your trapezius muscles.

5. Slowly lower your shoulders back down to the starting position, ensuring a controlled movement without completely relaxing your muscles.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions as mentioned by your trainer or prescribed in your workout routine.

Name: Dumbbell Over Bench One Arm Reverse Wrist Curl
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand, palm facing down.

2. Rest your forearm on the bench with your wrist extending slightly beyond the edge.

3. Slowly lower the dumbbell by flexing your wrist, allowing it to hang off the bench.

4. Maintaining control, raise the dumbbell back up by extending your wrist, curling it towards your forearm.

5. Repeat this wrist curl motion for the desired number of repetitions on one arm before switching to the other arm.

Name: Lever Seated Dip
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Latissimus Dorsi, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Sit on the lever seated dip machine with your back straight and firmly against the backrest.

2. Extend your arms and hold onto the handles of the machine, making sure your hands are shoulder-width apart.

3. Slowly lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the floor.

4. Keep your elbows pointed straight back and avoid letting your shoulders hunch forward.

5. Once you have reached the bottom of the movement, push through your palms to push yourself back up to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise according to your desired number of repetitions.

Name: Lever Seated Crunch
Description:
1. Sit on a crunching machine with your back against the backrest and your feet placed firmly on the footpads.

2. Grip the handles on both sides of the machine, ensuring your arms are bent at a 90-degree angle and your elbows are pointing forward.

3. Start by contracting your abdominal muscles and slowly lean back until your upper body is at a 45-degree angle from the ground. Keep your back straight throughout the movement.

4. From this position, engage your core and exhale as you lift your upper body back to the starting position by flexing your abs. Make sure to keep your lower back firmly pressed against the backrest.

5. At the top of the movement, pause for a second and squeeze your abs, then inhale as you slowly lower your upper body back to the 45-degree angle position.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining control and concentration on engaging your abdominal muscles throughout the exercise.

Remember to maintain proper form, control your movements, and consult a fitness professional if you have any concerns or questions regarding this exercise. Good luck with your workout!

Name: Lever Seated Twist
Description:
1. Sit on a chair with your back straight and your feet flat on the ground.

2. Hold a lever or any other weighted object in both hands in front of your chest.

3. Slowly twist your upper body to one side, keeping your hips and lower body facing forward.

4. Hold the twist for a few seconds, feeling the stretch in your oblique muscles.

5. Return to the starting position and then repeat the twist to the opposite side.

6. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Lever Seated Shoulder Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Sit down on the lever shoulder press machine, ensuring that your back is fully supported by the backrest.

2. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at shoulder level when you have a 90-degree bend at your elbows.

3. Grasp the handles with an overhand grip and make sure your palms are facing forward.

4. Begin the movement by pushing the handles up and away from your body, fully extending your arms without locking your elbows.

5. Hold the contracted position for a second, feeling the tension in your shoulder muscles.

6. Slowly lower the handles back to the starting position, maintaining control and resisting any momentum.

Name: Lever Chest Press (VERSION 2)
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Sit on the chest press machine with your feet flat on the ground.

2. Grasp the handles and position your hands shoulder-width apart. Your palms should be facing forward.

3. Engage your core and press the handles outward until your arms are fully extended, making sure to exhale during this movement.

4. Pause for a brief moment at the end of the movement, focusing on contracting your chest muscles.

5. Slowly and under control, bend your elbows to bring the handles back towards your chest while inhaling.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Barbell Standing Close Grip Military Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Hold a barbell with an overhand grip, placing your hands close together, just slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Start the exercise by lifting the barbell up to shoulder level, with your elbows pointing forward and your palms facing away from you. This is your starting position.

3. Engage your core and exhale as you use your shoulder and arm muscles to press the barbell straight up towards the ceiling, fully extending your arms. Keep your elbows pointing forward throughout the movement.

4. Once the barbell reaches the top, pause briefly to contract your shoulder muscles, then slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position. Control the movement and inhale as you lower the weight.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout.

Remember to start with a weight that you can handle safely and gradually increase the load as you become more comfortable and stronger in the exercise. It is also important to listen to your body and stop immediately if you feel any pain or discomfort. Always consult with a professional trainer or fitness expert before attempting any new exercises.

Name: Barbell Standing Wide Military Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasping the barbell with an overhand grip, hands wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Lift the barbell, making sure it rests on your upper chest with your elbows slightly in front of you and your forearms perpendicular to the floor.

3. Take a deep breath in and brace your core muscles.

4. Press the barbell straight overhead, fully extending your arms and maintaining control of the weight.

5. Once your arms are fully extended, hold the position briefly and then slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout.

(User executing the exercise) Remember to stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell with an overhand grip, and lift it up to rest on your upper chest. Then, take a deep breath, brace your core, and press the barbell straight overhead while fully extending your arms. Hold for a moment at the top, and then lower the barbell back down to the starting position. Keep repeating these steps without rushing the movement.

Name: EZ Barbell Seated Curls
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a bench and positioning your feet flat on the floor.

2. Grab an EZ barbell with an underhand grip, keeping your hands shoulder-width apart.

3. Rest your upper arms on the padding of the bench, ensuring that your elbows are fully extended.

4. Slowly curl the barbell towards your shoulders, engaging your biceps, while keeping your upper arms stationary.

5. Continue to curl until the barbell is almost touching your shoulders, pause briefly, then slowly lower the barbell back down to the starting position.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise by keeping your back straight and avoiding any jerking or swinging motions.

Name: Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
Description:
1. Begin by standing up straight with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a pair of dumbbells in your hands, with your palms facing your thighs.

2. Keeping your back straight and your core engaged, start by bending forward at the hips while simultaneously pushing your buttocks back. Lower the dumbbells in a controlled manner towards the ground, feeling a stretch in your hamstrings.

3. Continue lowering the dumbbells until you reach a point where you feel a comfortable stretch in your hamstrings, but be careful not to round your lower back excessively.

4. At the bottom of the movement, pause briefly, and then drive your hips forward while engaging your hamstrings and glutes. As you do this, start to stand upright, using the tension from your hamstrings to pull the dumbbells back up. Keep the dumbbells close to your legs throughout the movement.

5. Once you are standing upright and have squeezed your glutes, pause momentarily before repeating the exercise. Remember to maintain proper form and control throughout the entire movement.

6. Continue performing the dumbbell Romanian deadlift for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining a smooth and controlled motion while engaging your hamstring and glute muscles.

Name: Walking Lunge
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and your hands on your hips.

2. Take a step forward with your right foot, ensuring that your knee is bent at a 90-degree angle and your thigh is parallel to the ground.

3. While keeping your upper body straight, lower your left knee towards the ground by lowering your hips. Ensure that your right knee does not extend past your toes.

4. Push off with your right foot to bring your left leg forward into the next lunge position, repeating the same movement.

5. Continue alternating and moving forward, maintaining a controlled and steady pace.

6. Remember to engage your core, maintain proper posture, and breathe rhythmically throughout the exercise.

Name: Push-up on Forearms
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Start by getting into a push-up position on the floor, with your forearms and toes touching the ground.

2. Ensure that your elbows are directly under your shoulders, and your body forms a straight line from your head to your heels.

3. Engage your core muscles by tightening your abdominals and glutes.

4. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your forearms touch the ground, maintaining a solid plank position.

5. Push yourself back up by straightening your arms and returning to the starting position.

6. Repeat the movement while maintaining proper form and control.

Name: Lever Incline Chest Press (versions 2)
Description:
1. Adjust the seat height and position yourself on the lever incline chest press machine.

2. Grasp the handles with an overhand grip and make sure your elbows are slightly bent.

3. Push the handles forward by extending your elbows, while exhaling.

4. Hold the position for a moment and contract your chest muscles.

5. Slowly bring the handles back towards your chest, while inhaling.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember to follow a controlled and smooth motion throughout the exercise, maintaining proper form and breathing rhythm.

Name: Barbell Quarter Squat
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and positioning a barbell on the back of your shoulders, resting against your upper traps.

2. Lower your body down by bending your knees and hips to perform a quarter squat, aiming to bring your thighs parallel to the floor.

3. Ensure that your back remains straight and chest lifted throughout the movement, maintaining good posture.

4. Push through your heels to extend your hips and knees, returning to the starting position.

5. Repeat the quarter squat for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Barbell Olympic Squat
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and position the barbell across your upper back, resting it on your trapezius muscles. Make sure to double-check the weight is evenly distributed on both sides of the bar.

2. With a straight back and engaged core, start the movement by hinging at your hips and bending your knees to lower your body down. Keep your chest up and your gaze straight ahead.

3. Continue descending until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower, ensuring that your knees track over your toes and do not collapse inward.

4. Push through your heels and extend your legs and hips as you rise back up to the starting position. Keep your core tight and maintain an upright posture throughout the movement.

5. Exhale as you reach the top of the squat and prepare for your subsequent repetitions.

6. Remember to use a controlled and steady pace throughout the exercise to maintain proper form and maximize the benefits.

Name: Barbell full Zercher Squat
Description:
1. Start by placing the barbell on a squat rack at waist height and load it with an appropriate weight.

2. Stand facing towards the barbell and position your arms inside your legs, crossing them over each other with your hands gripping the barbell.

3. Take a few steps back and position your feet shoulder-width apart, with your toes slightly pointing outwards.

4. Keeping your core engaged and maintaining an upright posture, slowly lower your body by bending your knees and hips, as if sitting back into a chair. Keep the weight in your heels and ensure your knees are in line with your toes.

5. Continue lowering until your thighs are parallel to the ground, or as low as you can comfortably go. Pause for a second in this position.

6. Push through your heels and engage your glutes and leg muscles to slowly rise back up to the starting position. Stand tall and repeat the movement for the desired number of reps.

Remember to focus on proper form, maintaining control throughout the exercise, and consulting with a fitness professional if you have any concerns or questions about performing the exercise correctly. Good luck with your workout!

Name: Cable Standing Leg Curl
Description:
1. Begin by attaching an ankle cuff to the cable machine at floor level.

2. Stand facing the cable machine and place one foot into the ankle cuff. Adjust the strap so that it fits securely around your ankle.

3. Hold onto the cable machine for stability, keeping your core engaged and your upper body upright.

4. Slowly bend your knee of the leg that is in the ankle cuff, pulling your heel towards your glutes.

5. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, feeling the contraction in your hamstring.

6. Slowly lower your leg back down to the starting position, keeping control and tension in your hamstring muscles throughout the entire movement.

Name: Dumbbell Squat
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand, hanging by your sides.

2. Engage your core muscles and maintain an upright posture throughout the exercise.

3. Lower your body by bending at the hips and knees, as if sitting back into a chair. Keep your chest lifted and your knees aligned with your toes.

4. Continue descending until your thighs are parallel to the ground, or as low as you can comfortably go.

5. Push through your heels and extend your legs to raise your body back up to the starting position.

6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Lever Seated Wide Squat
Description:
1. Start by sitting on a bench or chair, ensuring that your feet are shoulder-width apart and your toes are pointing slightly outwards.

2. Place your hands on the lever handles located on each side of the seat, ensuring a firm grip.

3. Engage your core and begin to lower your body down into a squat position, making sure to keep your chest lifted and your back straight.

4. Continue to lower yourself until your thighs are parallel to the ground, or as close as you comfortably can. Make sure that your knees remain in line with your toes and avoid letting them go beyond your toes.

5. Push through your heels and engage your glutes and leg muscles to rise back up to the starting position, making sure to maintain a controlled and smooth movement throughout.

6. Repeat the squat motion for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring proper form and alignment throughout each repetition.

Remember to consult a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercises, especially if you are a beginner or have any underlying medical conditions or injuries.

Name: Sled Reverse Hack Squat
Description:
1. Set up the sled: Load weight plates onto the sled to your desired weight. Adjust the backrest and footplate to a comfortable position for your body.

2. Position yourself: Stand with your back against the backrest and place your feet on the footplate, shoulder-width apart. Keep your feet flat on the footplate and your knees slightly bent.

3. Descend into the squat: Engage your core and begin to lower your body by bending your knees and hips. Maintain a straight back and keep your chest up throughout the entire movement.

4. Push the sled: Once you have reached a comfortable depth in the squat, push against the footplate to extend your knees and hips, driving the sled backward. Continue pushing until your legs are fully extended and the sled is at the desired range of motion.

5. Return to starting position: Slowly and controlled, begin to bend your knees and hips again to lower the sled back to the original position. Maintain good form and control throughout the entire movement.

6. Repeat: Complete the desired number of repetitions for your workout, focusing on maintaining proper form, engaging your leg muscles, and utilizing the sled's resistance for an effective workout.

Name: Sit Squat
Description:
1. Sit Squat Exercise:

2. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outward.

3. Lower your body down into a deep squat position, keeping your heels on the ground and your back straight.

4. Once you have reached the squat position, lower your buttocks to the ground while maintaining balance and control.

5. Sit down fully on the ground, keeping your legs in a squat position and your heels still on the ground.

6. To stand back up, push through your heels and engage your leg muscles to lift your body back into a standing position, without using your hands for support.

Name: Smith Frankenstein Squat
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointed slightly outward.

2. Hold a barbell or a set of dumbbells in front of your shoulders, with your elbows bent and the weight resting on your upper chest.

3. Keeping your chest up and your back straight, slowly lower your body into a squat position by bending your knees and sitting back as if you were sitting on a chair. Aim to bring your thighs parallel to the ground.

4. As you descend into the squat, maintain a slight tilt forward at your hips, ensuring that your knees do not extend past your toes. This will help activate your glutes and hamstrings.

5. Once you reach the bottom position, push through your heels and press back up to the starting position, fully extending your hips and knees.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Smith Front Squat
Description:
1. Start by adjusting the Smith machine barbell to an appropriate height for your squatting position.

2. Stand facing the bar with your feet shoulder-width apart and your toes slightly turned out.

3. Reach forward and grip the bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Place the bar on your front delts, just in front of your shoulders, with your elbows pointing forward.

4. Engage your core, keep your chest up, and start the movement by pushing your hips back and bending your knees. Lower your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground or slightly below, ensuring your knees don't go beyond your toes.

5. Push through your heels and extend your knees and hips simultaneously to return to the starting position, keeping your chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.

6. Repeat the exercise for the prescribed number of repetitions.

Name: Smith Squat to Bench
Description:
1. Begin by positioning yourself under the Smith machine bar, with the barbell resting on the safety pins or hooks at hip level.

2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and slightly in front of the bar, ensuring a stable and balanced position.

3. Bend your knees and lower your body down into a squat, aiming to bring your thighs parallel to the ground or slightly lower.

4. Keep your upper body upright, maintaining a straight back and bracing your core for stability.

5. Slowly push through your feet and extend your knees and hips to stand back up, returning to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement.

As a final user executing the exercise, remember to always warm up properly before starting any exercise routine, and adjust the weight on the Smith machine to a level that challenges you without compromising your form.

Name: Smith Stiff Legged Deadlift
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, with the barbell resting on the floor in front of you.

2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips, keeping your back straight and chest lifted.

3. Grab the barbell with an overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

4. Begin the movement by pushing your hips back and lowering the barbell towards the floor, keeping the legs mostly straight but with a slight bend in the knees.

5. Lower the barbell as far as your flexibility allows, maintaining a strong and stable core throughout the movement.

6. Engage your glutes and hamstrings to reverse the movement, driving your hips forward and slowly raising the barbell back up to the starting position, maintaining control and keeping the back straight.

Name: Smith Zercher Squat
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and position the barbell on the ground in front of you.

2. Bend down and grip the barbell with an underhand grip, placing your arms inside your thighs and crossing them over each other.

3. Engage your core and lift the barbell by straightening your arms and bringing it up to your upper chest, keeping your elbows tucked in close to your body.

4. Once you have a secure grip on the barbell, lower your body into a squat position by bending at the hips and knees. Ensure your feet stay flat on the ground and your knees are in line with your toes.

5. Continue lowering your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground, or as low as your flexibility allows. Maintain an upright torso and avoid leaning forward excessively.

6. Push through your heels to stand back up, extending your hips and knees. Keep the barbell close to your body throughout the movement.

Remember to consult a fitness professional before attempting any new exercise to ensure proper form and technique.

Name: Cable Triceps Pushdown (SZ-bar)
Description:
1. Attach a SZ-bar to the cable machine, making sure it's at a height that allows you to comfortably grab it with an overhand grip.

2. Stand facing the cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent for stability.

3. Grip the SZ-bar with your palms facing downward and your hands shoulder-width apart. Keep your elbows tucked close to your sides and your upper arms stationary throughout the exercise.

4. Engage your core and start by fully extending your elbows, pushing the SZ-bar down until your arms are fully straight, but without locking out your elbows.

5. Pause for a moment at the bottom, then slowly allow the SZ-bar to rise back up to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Name: Cable Reverse Grip Triceps Pushdown (SZ-bar)
Description:
1. Attach a SZ-bar to the cable machine at a high pulley position.

2. Stand facing the machine and grab the SZ-bar with an underhand grip (palms facing upward) and hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Position your feet shoulder-width apart, with a slight bend in your knees for stability.

4. Start with your arms bent at a 90-degree angle, with your elbows close to your sides and in line with your torso.

5. Engaging your triceps, exhale as you press the bar downward by extending your arms fully until they are straight.

6. Hold the contraction for a brief pause, while focusing on squeezing your triceps.

7. Inhale as you slowly release the bar back to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

8. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Note: Remember to choose an appropriate weight that challenges your triceps without compromising your form. Keep your core engaged and maintain a slight forward lean, while avoiding excessive swinging or using momentum during the exercise.

Name: Cable Biceps Curl (SZ-bar)
Description:
1. Stand facing the cable machine with your feet hip-width apart and a SZ-bar attachment attached to a low pulley.

2. Grab the SZ-bar attachment with an underhand grip, palms facing up, and keep your elbows tucked close to your sides.

3. Begin by exhaling and slowly curling the bar up towards your shoulders, keeping your upper arms stationary.

4. Hold the contracted position for a brief pause while squeezing your biceps.

5. Slowly inhale and lower the bar back down to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Cable Reverse Grip Biceps Curl (SZ-bar)
Description:
1. Stand in front of a cable machine and grasp the SZ-bar with an underhand, reverse grip. Your palms should be facing upwards.

2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent for stability. Keep your back upright and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

3. Start with your arms fully extended and your elbows close to your sides. This is your starting position.

4. Keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the SZ-bar towards your shoulders by flexing your biceps. Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.

5. Pause for a brief moment at the top of the contraction, and then inhale as you slowly lower the SZ-bar back to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

6. Repeat the movement for the recommended number of repetitions, maintaining control and a slow, controlled tempo throughout the exercise.

Name: Cable One Arm Side Triceps Pushdown
Description:
1. Stand facing a cable machine, about arm's length away, with one handle attachment at the lowest height.

2. Grab the handle with one hand and stand with your side towards the machine, keeping your feet shoulder-width apart.

3. Extend your arm fully and bring it to the side of your body, keeping your elbow close to your torso.

4. While maintaining a straight arm, exhale and push the handle downwards towards your thigh until your hand is next to your thigh.

5. Hold for a brief moment, squeezing your triceps at the bottom of the movement.

6. Inhale as you slowly release the handle back to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Name: Barbell Behind Back Finger Curl
Description:
1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with an overhand grip behind your back.

2. Keeping your upper arms stationary, slowly curl the barbell towards your body by flexing your fingers.

3. Continue curling the barbell until your fingers are fully contracted and the barbell is close to your body.

4. Pause for a moment, then slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form throughout.

Hey there! Here are the steps for the Barbell Behind Back Finger Curl:

6. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and hold the barbell behind your back.

7. Curl the barbell towards your body by flexing your fingers, while keeping your upper arms still.

8. Keep curling until your fingers are fully contracted and the barbell is close to your body.

9. Pause briefly, then slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.
Remember to focus on your form and perform the desired number of repetitions. Good luck!

Name: Lever Preacher Curl (version 2)
Description:
1. Sit on the preacher curl machine and adjust the seat and arm pad to a comfortable position.

2. Grab the lever handle with an underhand grip, palms facing up, and position your upper arms flat against the arm pad.

3. Keep your back straight, engage your core, and slowly curl the lever up towards your shoulders, exhaling as you lift.

4. Hold the topmost position for a brief pause, focusing on contracting your biceps, then slowly lower the lever back down to the starting position, inhaling as you lower.

5. Repeat the controlled curling movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Lever Hammer Grip Preacher Curl
Description:
1. Sit on a preacher curl bench and position your arms against the angled pad, ensuring your feet are flat on the floor.

2. Grasp the lever hammer grip barbell with an underhand grip, with your hands shoulder-width apart.

3. While keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the lever hammer grip barbell towards your shoulders by contracting your biceps.

4. Hold the contraction for a second and squeeze your biceps.

5. Inhale and slowly lower the lever hammer grip barbell back to the starting position, maintaining control.

Name: Lever Reverse Grip Preacher Curl
Description:
1. Sit on the preacher curl bench and position your upper arms on the pad, while grasping the barbell with an underhand grip (palms facing upwards).

2. Adjust the lever arm so that it aligns with your chest height and place your feet flat on the ground, ensuring a stable and balanced position.

3. Keeping your upper arms firmly against the pad, exhale and slowly curl the barbell towards your shoulders by contracting your biceps. Keep your elbows stationary throughout the movement.

4. Once you have fully contracted your biceps and the barbell is close to your shoulders, squeeze your muscles for a brief moment.

5. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position while inhaling, maintaining control over the weight and keeping your upper arms against the pad.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on the proper form and engaging your biceps during the entire exercise.

Name: Dumbbell Palms In Incline Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Lie down on an incline bench with your back supported and feet placed firmly on the ground.

2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand, with your palms facing towards each other and arms extended upwards perpendicular to the floor.

3. Take a deep breath, brace your core, and slowly lower the dumbbells towards your chest, maintaining control and keeping your elbows tucked in.

4. Exhale and press the dumbbells back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms without locking your elbows.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Dumbbell Reverse Bench Press
Description:
1. Lie down on a flat bench with your feet flat on the ground, holding a dumbbell in each hand.

2. Start with your arms extended straight above your chest, palms facing downwards.

3. Keeping your elbows slightly bent, slowly lower the dumbbells towards your shoulders in a controlled manner.

4. Once the dumbbells are at shoulder level, reverse the movement and push them back up to the starting position.

5. Make sure to engage your chest, shoulders, and triceps throughout the exercise to maximize the benefits.

Remember to consult a professional trainer or coach before attempting any new exercise to ensure proper form and technique.

Name: Smith Machine Decline Close Grip Bench Press
Description:
1. Set the Smith machine to a decline angle, ensuring that it's at a comfortable position for you.

2. Lie down on the bench facing upwards and place your feet firmly on the floor. Grab the bar with a grip slightly narrower than shoulder width, making sure your palms are facing each other.

3. Unlock the bar from the Smith machine and lower it slowly towards your chest, while maintaining control and keeping your elbows tucked in close to your body. Stop once the bar is just above your chest.

4. Push the bar upward by extending your arms, while exhaling. Try to keep your elbows close to your body during this movement. Fully extend your arms without locking your elbows at the top of the movement.

5. Pause briefly at the top, maintaining tension in your chest and triceps, before lowering the bar back down to the starting position in a controlled manner. Inhale as you lower the bar.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Remember to always consult with a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercise, especially if you are new to weightlifting or have any underlying health conditions.

Name: Smith Machine Reverse Decline Close Grip Bench Press
Description:
1. Position yourself on the decline bench with your back against the pad and your feet placed firmly on the floor.

2. Grip the bar on a Smith machine using a close grip, with your palms facing towards you and your hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width apart.

3. Extend your arms fully and lift the bar off the Smith machine, making sure to maintain control and stability.

4. Slowly lower the bar towards your lower chest, keeping your elbows tucked in close to your body as you descend.

5. Pause briefly when the bar reaches your chest, then push it back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms and keeping your core engaged throughout the movement.

Note: Remember to always use proper form, control the weight, and consult a professional trainer if you have any concerns about your technique or ability to perform the exercise safely.

Name: EZ Barbell Close Grip Preacher Curl
Description:
1. Sit down on a preacher curl bench and position yourself so that your upper arms are resting comfortably on the pad, while your chest is pressed against it.

2. Grip the EZ barbell with your hands positioned close together, palms facing upwards. Make sure your hands are slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Keeping your upper arms stationary and pressed against the pad, exhale and slowly curl the barbell upwards towards your shoulders, while contracting your biceps. Ensure that only your forearms are moving during this motion.

4. Pause momentarily at the top of the movement, then inhale and slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the descent.

5. Repeat the above steps for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and squeezing your biceps at the top of each repetition.

It is important to consult with a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercise to ensure proper form and technique.

Name: Barbell Standing Wide Grip Biceps Curl
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp a barbell with an overhand grip, your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

2. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell upwards towards your shoulders, exhaling as you lift.

3. Ensure that your upper arms remain stationary throughout the movement, with only your forearms moving.

4. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, squeezing your biceps before slowly lowering the barbell back down to the starting position, inhaling as you lower.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Please note that it's important to warm up before starting any exercise and to consult with a fitness professional if you have any specific concerns or limitations.

Name: Cable Close Grip Curl
Description:
1. Stand in front of a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position and attach a straight bar to it.

2. Start by grasping the bar with an underhand, close grip (hands shoulder-width apart) and let your arms fully extend, keeping your back straight.

3. Keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the bar towards your chest by contracting your biceps. Keep your elbows close to your sides throughout the movement.

4. Continue curling until you feel a good contraction in your biceps, then hold the position for a brief moment while squeezing your biceps.

5. Slowly inhale as you lower the bar back to the starting position, fully extending your arms and feeling a stretch in your biceps.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, focusing on controlled movements and avoiding swinging or using momentum.

Name: Cable Concentration Curl
Description:
1. Begin by attaching a single handle to a low pulley on a cable machine.

2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart, standing approximately one foot away from the cable machine.

3. Grab the handle with an underhand grip, keeping your elbow close to your side and your arm fully extended.

4. Start the movement by curling your forearm as you bring the handle towards your shoulder, allowing your biceps to contract.

5. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement, ensuring your elbow stays in a fixed position.

6. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the entire motion.

Now that you're familiar with the steps, go ahead and start the exercise. Remember to maintain proper form and engage your biceps throughout the movement.

Name: Cable Drag Curl
Description:
1. Stand facing a cable machine, feet shoulder-width apart, and grasp the cable attachment with an underhand grip.

2. Maintain a slight bend in your knees and ensure your core is engaged for stability.

3. Keeping your elbows close to your sides, exhale and curl the cable attachment towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.

4. Hold the contraction for a brief moment, focusing on feeling the tension in your biceps.

5. Inhale and slowly lower the cable attachment back to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Remember to select a weight that challenges you but still allows you to maintain proper form throughout the exercise. Enjoy your workout and feel the burn in your biceps!

Name: Cable Overhead Curl
Description:
1. Stand facing away from the cable machine with feet shoulder-width apart.

2. Grab the cable handle with an underhand grip and extend your arms straight overhead.

3. Keep your elbows tucked in and slowly lower the cable handle behind your head by bending at the elbows, while maintaining the straight position of your upper arms.

4. Pause for a second in this position, feeling the stretch in your biceps and shoulders.

5. Engage your biceps and slowly return to the starting position by extending your arms back overhead.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining control and proper form throughout the exercise.

Name: Cable Seated Curl
Description:
1. Sit on a cable machine bench with your back straight and feet flat on the floor.

2. Grasp the cable handles with an underhand grip, keeping your arms fully extended and hands shoulder-width apart.

3. Engage your core muscles and maintain a stable position throughout the exercise.

4. Slowly bend your elbows and bring your hands towards your shoulders while keeping your upper arms stationary.

5. Contract your biceps at the top of the movement, making sure to squeeze them for a brief moment.

6. Slowly lower the cable handles back down to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

Remember to breathe steadily throughout the exercise and focus on using your biceps to control the movement. Adjust the weight and cable height as necessary to suit your strength and comfort level.

Name: Dumbbell Biceps Curl Reverse
Description:
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing towards your body.

2. Start with your arms fully extended down by your sides, keeping your elbows close to your body.

3. Slowly curl the dumbbells upwards while maintaining a tight grip, making sure to engage your biceps. As you curl, twist your palms to face upwards, away from your body.

4. Continue lifting the dumbbells until your forearms are parallel to the ground and your biceps are fully contracted. Maintain a controlled and steady movement throughout the exercise.

5. Pause for a brief moment, keeping tension on your biceps at the top of the movement.

6. Reverse the motion, gradually lowering the dumbbells back down to the starting position with your palms facing your body again.

Note: It is important to maintain proper form and avoid using momentum to swing the weights. Focus on a slow and deliberate movement to fully engage your biceps throughout the exercise.

Name: Dumbbell Cross Body Hammer Curl (Version 2)
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing towards your body.

2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and slowly curl one dumbbell up towards the opposite shoulder. In other words, your left hand should curl the dumbbell to your right shoulder and your right hand to your left shoulder.

3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement and pause briefly.

4. Slowly lower the dumbbell back down to the starting position while maintaining control and keeping your body stable.

5. Repeat the movement with the opposite arm, curling the dumbbell up towards the opposite shoulder.
Note: Remember to focus on proper form and control throughout the exercise to maximize its effectiveness.

Name: Dumbbell High Curl
Description:
1. Start by standing upright with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand with an underhand grip.

2. Keeping your back straight and your elbows close to your sides, slowly curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while exhaling.

3. Focus on contracting your biceps at the top of the curl and hold for a brief pause. This is the peak contraction point.

4. Lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position in a controlled manner, while inhaling.

5. Repeat the curl for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form throughout the exercise.

Remember to start with a weight that allows you to perform the exercise correctly and gradually increase the weight as you gain strength.

Name: Dumbbell Seated Bicep Curl
Description:
1. Sit on a bench or chair with your back upright and your feet firmly planted on the ground.

2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms fully extended down by your sides and your palms facing forward.

3. Keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while contracting your biceps.

4. Continue to curl the dumbbells upwards until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level.

5. Pause for a moment, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.

6. Inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

7. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

When performing the Dumbbell Seated Bicep Curl, remember to maintain good posture, engage your core, and avoid swinging your body to generate momentum. Focus on contracting your biceps throughout the exercise and control the movement as you curl the dumbbells up and lower them back down.

Name: Dumbbell Seated Hammer Curl
Description:
1. Sit on a bench or chair with your feet flat on the ground and hold a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing inwards.

2. Keep your back straight and engage your core muscles.

3. Bend your elbows and curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, while keeping your upper arms stationary.

4. Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement for maximum contraction.

5. Slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position, while maintaining control and not letting your elbows fully extend.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: EZ Bar Seated Close Grip Concentration Curl
Description:
1. Sit down on a flat bench and hold an EZ bar with an underhand grip, with your hands placed slightly narrower than shoulder-width apart.

2. Rest your elbows on the inside of your thighs, near the knees, and let the bar hang in front of you, palms facing upwards.

3. Slowly curl the EZ bar towards your chest, keeping your upper arms stationary and your elbows locked in position against your thighs. Focus on squeezing your biceps as you lift the weight.

4. Continue curling until the bar is close to touching your chest, while maintaining control and avoiding any swinging or rocking motions.

5. Pause briefly at the top of the movement, feeling the peak contraction in your biceps.

6. Lower the EZ bar in a controlled manner back to the starting position, fully extending your arms and allowing the weight to hang down in front of you. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Remember to always use a weight that is suitable for your fitness level and to maintain proper form throughout the exercise.

Name: Smith Machine Bicep Curl
Description:
1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart, facing the Smith machine.

2. Adjust the height of the bar on the Smith machine to your desired position, usually at hip-level or slightly higher.

3. Grasp the bar with an underhand grip, with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

4. Keep your upper arms stationary and your elbows tucked in close to your sides. Slowly curl the bar towards your shoulders, while keeping your wrists straight and maintaining a controlled movement.

5. Pause for a brief moment at the top of the movement, squeezing your biceps.

6. Slowly lower the bar back down to the starting position, fully extending your arms but keeping tension in your biceps throughout the exercise.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, engaging your core muscles for stability. Start with a weight that allows you to perform the exercise with correct technique, gradually increasing the weight as you become more comfortable and confident in your abilities.

Name: Barbell Seated Close grip Behind Neck Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Sit on a bench with your back straight and grasp a barbell with a close grip.

2. Lift the barbell overhead and keep it positioned slightly behind your head, with your elbows bent and upper arms perpendicular to the floor.

3. Slowly extend your arms and straighten them until the barbell is directly above your head, making sure to keep your elbows close to your head throughout the movement.

4. Once your arms are fully extended, hold the position briefly and squeeze your triceps.

5. Slowly return the barbell to the starting position by bending your elbows and lowering the weight back behind your head.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Barbell Incline Close Grip Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Begin by setting up a bench on an incline (usually between 30-45 degrees).

2. Lay back on the bench and firmly grip the barbell with a close grip, slightly narrower than shoulder-width apart.

3. Lift the barbell off the rack and position it directly above your upper chest, with your arms fully extended.

4. Lower the barbell slowly and with control towards your chest, while keeping your elbows close to your body.

5. Pause briefly when the barbell touches your chest, then push the barbell back up to the starting position by extending your arms fully.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Barbell Lying Back of the Head Tricep Extension
Description:
1. Start by lying on a flat bench with your feet planted firmly on the ground and your knees bent.

2. Grasp a barbell with an overhand grip, hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Extend your arms straight up towards the ceiling, directly above your chest, with the barbell resting on your palms.

4. Slowly lower the barbell towards the back of your head, allowing your elbows to bend and your forearms to move behind your head.

5. Pause momentarily at the bottom of the movement, feeling a stretch in your triceps.

6. Engage your triceps to straighten your arms and lift the barbell back to the starting position above your chest.

7. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout.

Remember to always use a weight that is appropriate for your fitness level and to warm up properly before performing any exercise.

Name: Barbell Reverse Grip Skullcrusher
Description:
1. Lie flat on a bench with your feet planted firmly on the ground and a barbell placed on the rack just above your head.

2. Grab the barbell with an underhand grip (palms facing upward), positioning your hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width apart.

3. Lift the barbell off the rack and hold it directly above your forehead with your arms fully extended.

4. Inhale and bend your elbows to slowly lower the barbell towards your forehead, keeping your upper arms stationary and perpendicular to the floor.

5. Exhale and extend your arms, pushing the barbell back up to the starting position without locking out your elbows.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Cable High Pulley Overhead Tricep Extension
Description:
1. Begin by standing in an upright position facing the cable machine, with your feet shoulder-width apart and a slight bend in your knees.

2. Grasp the high pulley bar with an overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Keeping your upper arms still, engage your core and slowly extend your forearms backward while exhaling until your arms are fully stretched out behind your head. Your elbows should be pointing upward and your upper arms should remain stationary throughout the movement.

4. Hold the contraction for a brief pause, squeezing the triceps, and then inhale as you slowly bring the cable bar back to the starting position, allowing your forearms to flex back.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining control and a steady pace throughout.

Name: Cable Rope Incline Tricep Extension
Description:
1. Adjust the cable machine to a height slightly above your head level.

2. Attach a rope handle to the cable and stand facing away from the machine.

3. Grab the rope with an overhand grip, keeping your hands close together, and step forward a few feet to create tension in the cable.

4. Lean slightly forward, engaging your core muscles, and position your elbows close to your head, upper arms parallel to the ground.

5. Keeping your upper arms stationary, extend your forearms by straightening your elbows. Focus on contracting your triceps muscles as you push the rope downwards.

6. Pause for a brief moment at the bottom of the movement, then slowly return to the starting position by bending your elbows back while maintaining control throughout the motion.

Name: Cable Two Arm Tricep Kickback
Description:
1. Stand facing a cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart and a slight bend in your knees.

2. Grasp the cable handles with an overhand grip, making sure your palms are facing each other.

3. Keeping your upper arms close to your body and your elbows tucked in, exhale and extend your arms backwards.

4. Focus on fully extending your arms while feeling the contraction in your triceps.

5. Hold the contraction for a brief moment and then inhale as you slowly bring your forearms back to the starting position.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps, ensuring proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Dumbbell Lying Single Extension
Description:
1. Lie flat on a bench with your back pressed against it and feet firmly planted on the ground.

2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand, with your palm facing inward and arm extended straight up towards the ceiling.

3. Keeping your upper arm still, slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbow.

4. Once your forearm is parallel to the ground, pause briefly and then slowly extend your arm back up to the starting position.

5. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions before switching to the other arm.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise and engage your core muscles for stability.

Name: Dumbbell Standing Bent Over Two Arm Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and holding a dumbbell in each hand.

2. Hinge forward at your hips, keeping your back straight, until your torso is parallel to the floor. This is the starting position.

3. Bend your elbows and raise the dumbbells to your sides, making sure your upper arms stay close to your body. Your palms should be facing each other.

4. Keeping your upper arms stationary, straighten your arms fully by extending your elbows. Exhale as you do this movement, feeling the contraction in your triceps.

5. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, squeezing your triceps.

6. Slowly bend your elbows to bring the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Remember to start with lighter weights and gradually increase the weight as you become more comfortable with the exercise. Proper form and control are essential to maximize the effectiveness of this triceps exercise. Good luck with your workout!

Name: Smith Machine Incline Tricep Extension
Description:
1. Adjust the seat and bar height on the Smith machine to ensure proper alignment with your upper body.
