2. Stand facing away from the machine, positioning yourself in a slight staggered stance for stability.

3. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

4. Lean forward at the waist while keeping your back straight and core engaged, creating a slight bend in the knees.

5. Slowly lower the bar towards the back of your head while maintaining control and keeping your elbows in a fixed position.

6. Pause momentarily when the bar is just above your head, then exhale and extend your arms, pushing the bar back up to the starting position.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and controlled movement throughout.

Please note that it's crucial to consult with a fitness professional or trainer before attempting any new exercise, especially if you're unsure about proper form or have any existing injuries.

Name: Dumbbell Goblet Squat
Synergist: Adductor Magnus, Gluteus Medius, Soleus, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, and hold a dumbbell vertically against your chest with both hands.

2. Brace your core and maintain an upright torso as you lower your body down into a squat position, pushing your hips back and bending your knees.

3. Keep your chest lifted and your elbows pointing forward throughout the movement.

4. When your thighs are parallel to the ground, pause for a moment, and then push through your heels to return to the starting position, fully extending your legs.

5. Continue performing the dumbbell goblet squat with controlled movements, maintaining proper form and breathing throughout the exercise.

Name: Hanging Oblique Knee Raise
Synergist: Adductor Brevis, Adductor Longus, Adductor Magnus, Gluteus Medius, Gracilis, Quadriceps, Rectus Abdominis, Sartorius, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you and your arms fully extended.

2. Engage your core muscles and slightly bend your knees.

3. Lift your legs up towards your left side while twisting your torso, bringing your knees towards your left elbow. Keep your upper body stable throughout the movement.

4. Pause for a moment and then slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position.

5. Repeat the movement, this time lifting your legs towards your right side, bringing your knees towards your right elbow.

6. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Be sure to maintain proper form throughout the exercise and focus on using your abs to initiate the movement. Keep the movement controlled and avoid swinging or using momentum to lift your legs. Good luck with your workout!

Name: Single Leg Squat with Support (pistol)
Description:
1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and slightly bend your knees.

2. Extend one leg straight out in front of you, parallel to the ground, while keeping your core engaged and arms extended straight out.

3. Slowly lower your body down into a squat position on your supporting leg, making sure to keep your knee aligned with your foot.

4. Push through your heel, engage your glutes, and use your supporting leg to lift your body back up to the starting position.

5. Repeat the exercise on the other leg, ensuring you maintain proper form and control throughout the movement.

Remember to always consult with a fitness professional or your doctor before attempting new exercises, especially if you have any existing injuries or conditions.

Name: Shoulder Grip Pull-up
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Start by standing underneath a pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you, shoulder-width apart.

2. Reach up and firmly grip the bar with your hands, making sure to maintain a shoulder-width distance between them.

3. Hang from the bar while keeping your body straight and fully extended. Engage your core and squeeze your shoulder blades together.

4. Pull your body up towards the bar by engaging your back and arm muscles. Aim to bring your chin above the level of the bar.

5. Slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position, fully extending your arms and maintaining tension in your muscles.

6. Repeat the exercise, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout each repetition.

Remember to consult with a fitness professional or trainer to ensure proper technique and to determine the appropriate number of repetitions and sets for your fitness level.

Name: Hanging Leg Hip Raise
Synergist: Obliques, Quadriceps, Sartorius, Tensor Fasciae Latae
Description:
1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended and your legs slightly bent.

2. Engage your core muscles by pulling your belly button towards your spine and keeping your back straight.

3. Slowly lift your legs by bending at the hips, while keeping them straight and together, until they are parallel to the floor.

4. Pause at the top of the movement, squeezing your lower abs.

5. Lower your legs back down to the starting position in a controlled manner, making sure to avoid swinging or using momentum.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Keep in mind that the hanging leg hip raise primarily targets your lower abs and hip flexors, so it is important to focus on engaging those muscles throughout the movement. Good luck with your workout! Let me know if you have any more questions.

Name: Dumbbell Upright Row (back POV)
Description:
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended down in front of you.

2. Keep your back straight and your core engaged throughout the exercise.

3. Slowly lift the dumbbells straight up towards your chin, leading with your elbows, while keeping the weights close to your body.

4. Keep lifting until the dumbbells are just below your chin, pause momentarily, and then slowly lower them back down to the starting position.

5. Repeat the lifting and lowering motion for the recommended number of repetitions. 

Remember to use a weight that challenges you but still allows you to maintain proper form throughout the exercise. Keep your movements slow and controlled, focusing on the muscles in your upper back and shoulders.

Name: Cable Kneeling Triceps Extension (VERSION 2)
Description:
1. Start by setting up a cable machine with a rope attachment at a high position.

2. Position yourself on your knees, facing away from the machine, with your upper body upright and your core engaged.

3. Grab the rope with an overhand grip and extend your arms straight overhead, keeping your elbows close to your ears.

4. Lower the rope by bending at the elbows, allowing them to move backward and away from your head while maintaining tension on the cable.

5. Continue lowering the rope until your forearms are parallel to the floor or slightly below, feeling a stretch in your triceps.

6. Engage your triceps to reverse the movement and extend your arms back up to the starting position, focusing on squeezing your triceps at the top.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining control and proper form throughout.

Name: Hyperextension (VERSION 2)
Description:
1. Lie face down on an exercise mat or bench, with your hips and upper body supported and your legs straight behind you.

2. Place your hands either at the sides of your head or crossed over your chest.

3. Slowly lift your upper body off the mat, engaging your lower back muscles, and maintain a straight line from your head to your heels.

4. Exhale and squeeze your glutes as you lift your upper body as high as comfortably possible. Hold this position for a brief moment.

5. Inhale as you slowly lower your upper body back down to the starting position, ensuring that your neck and spine remain aligned.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise and listen to your body. Adjust the range of motion and intensity based on your comfort level.

Name: Cable Curl with Multipurpose V bar
Description:
1. Stand facing the cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart, ensuring the machine is set at a height that allows your arms to fully extend. Grab a multipurpose V bar attachment with an underhand grip, palms facing up.

2. Keep your upper arms stationary and positioned against the sides of your torso, engage your core, and exhale as you curl the bar upwards towards your shoulders. Ensure that your wrists remain straight and locked in position throughout the movement.

3. As you reach the top of the curl, squeeze your biceps and hold the contraction for a brief moment. Focus on maintaining control and avoiding any swinging or jerking motions.

4. Inhale and slowly lower the bar back to the starting position, ensuring a controlled eccentric (negative) phase. Your arms should be fully extended, but avoid locking your elbows at the bottom.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and technique throughout. Remember to breathe consistently and not let your body sway or use momentum to lift the weight.

Note: It is important to consult with a fitness professional or certified trainer before attempting any new exercises to ensure proper form and technique.

Name: Extra Decline Sit-up
Description:
1. Lie down on an inclined exercise bench with your feet secured under the provided foot pads.

2. Place your hands behind your head or crossed over your chest, whichever is more comfortable for you.

3. Engage your core muscles by tightening your abs and glutes.

4. Slowly lift your upper body off the bench by flexing your spine, keeping your chin tucked to your chest.

5. Continue the upward movement until your torso is approximately perpendicular to the floor.

6. Slowly lower your upper body back down to the starting position, emphasizing control and maintaining tension in your abdominal muscles.

Name: Hammer Grip Pull-up on Dip Cage
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Step up to the dip cage and place your hands on the parallel bars, palms facing each other, in a hammer grip position.

2. Engage your core and make sure your shoulders are relaxed.

3. Begin the exercise by pulling yourself up, using the strength of your back and arms. You should aim to bring your chest close to the bars.

4. Pause for a brief moment at the top of the movement, squeezing your back muscles and biceps.

5. Slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position, maintaining control and avoiding any swinging or jerking motions.

Remember to always prioritize proper form and technique to avoid any injuries. Good luck with your workout! Let me know if you have any other questions.

Name: Wide Grip Pull-Up on Dip Cage
Description:
1. Stand facing the dip cage with your feet shoulder-width apart.

2. Reach up and grab the horizontal bars of the dip cage with an overhand grip that is wider than your shoulder width.

3. Hang freely from the bars, allowing your arms to fully extend and taking a comfortable grip on the bars.

4. Engage your core and pull your shoulder blades down and back to initiate the movement.

5. Keep your elbows pointed outwards and slowly raise your body upward by pulling your chest towards the bars until your chin is slightly above the bars.

6. Pause for a second at the top of the movement, squeezing your back muscles.

7. Slowly lower your body back down to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

Name: Lever Seated Hip Adduction (VERSION 2)
Description:
1. Begin by sitting upright on the lever seated hip adduction machine, with your back against the pad and your feet flat on the footrests.

2. Adjust the machine so that your thighs are positioned parallel to the ground and your knees are at a 90-degree angle.

3. Place your arms on the side handles or grip the front handles of the machine for stability.

4. Engage your inner thigh muscles and slowly press your thighs together, squeezing the pads on the machine.

5. Hold the squeeze for a couple of seconds, making sure to keep your core engaged and your back straight.

6. Slowly release the pads and return to the starting position, allowing your thighs to open back up without fully extending your legs.

Name: Barbell Low Bar Squat with Rack
Description:
1. Begin by setting up the barbell at a low position on a squat rack. Make sure the bar is secure and properly aligned with your midline.

2. Stand facing the barbell with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Position your feet so that they are pointing slightly outward.

3. Approach the bar and position yourself underneath it, ensuring your upper back is in contact with the barbell.

4. Grasp the barbell with a wide and overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Your hands should be positioned on the bar in a way that allows your wrists to remain neutral throughout the movement.

5. Once you have a secure grip on the barbell, unrack it by fully extending your hips and knees. Step back slightly to clear the squat rack and take a moment to find your balance.

6. Begin the squat by bending your hips and knees simultaneously, lowering your body down towards the floor. Keep your chest up and your back straight as you descend, ensuring your knees track over your toes.

7. Go as low as your flexibility allows or until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement.

8. Drive through your heels and extend your hips and knees to return to the starting position. Keep your core engaged and maintain proper form throughout the entire movement.

Remember to start with a lighter weight and gradually increase as you become more comfortable with the exercise. Always prioritize safety and proper form to maximize the benefits of the exercise.

Name: Lever Seated Hip Abduction (VERSION 2)
Description:
1. Sit on the lever seated hip abduction machine with your back against the backrest and your feet flat on the footrests.

2. Adjust the footrests so that they are positioned comfortably against the inside of your thighs.

3. Place your hands on the side handles of the machine to provide stability.

4. Begin the exercise by pushing your legs outward against the footrests, opening your legs in a controlled motion.

5. Continue pushing until you reach a comfortable range of motion, making sure to keep your knees and feet pointing forward.

6. Slowly return to the starting position by bringing your legs back together, resisting the weight of the machine as you close your legs.

Remember to always consult a professional trainer or instructor before attempting any exercise to ensure correct form and prevent injury.

Name: Lever Lateral Pulldown (plate loaded)
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Sit down on the Lever Lateral Pulldown machine and adjust the seat height so that your feet are flat on the floor.

2. Grasp the handles with an overhand grip, extending your arms fully and ensuring that your hands are slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

3. Keep your back straight and engage your core muscles. Lean slightly back, maintaining a slight bend in your elbows throughout the exercise.

4. In a smooth, controlled motion, pull the handles down towards your chest by squeezing your shoulder blades together. Focus on using your back muscles to initiate the movement.

5. Once the handles reach your chest, pause briefly and then slowly reverse the motion, allowing the handles to rise back up to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form throughout the movement.

Remember to start with a weight that allows you to perform the exercise with proper form and gradually increase the resistance as you become more comfortable and stronger. Also, always consult with a fitness professional or trainer to ensure you are using correct technique to avoid injuries.

Name: Lever Triceps Dip (plate loaded)
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Latissimus Dorsi, Levator Scapulae, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Sit on the lever triceps dip machine, ensuring that your back is against the backrest and your feet are planted firmly on the footplate.

2. Grasp the handles of the machine with an overhand grip, making sure your hands are shoulder-width apart and your elbows are slightly bent.

3. Engage your core muscles and slowly straighten your arms, using the strength of your triceps to push the handles down towards your sides.

4. Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement, feeling a stretch in your triceps, and then slowly return to the starting position by bending your elbows.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, keeping your body still and focusing on engaging your triceps throughout the exercise.

Remember to adjust the weight of the machine according to your strength level and always consult a fitness professional to ensure proper form and technique. Keep in mind that individual results and abilities may vary.

Name: Lever Preacher Curl (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Sit on the preacher curl bench with your feet flat on the floor and your knees at a 90-degree angle.

2. Place your upper arms against the preacher pad and grab the lever handles with an underhand grip, keeping your palms facing upward.

3. Slowly lower the lever handles towards your forearms, allowing your biceps to stretch as you maintain control throughout the movement.

4. Once your biceps are fully stretched, use the strength in your arms to curl the lever handles upwards, while exhaling.

5. Continue to curl until the handles are close to your shoulders, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.

Name: Lever Leg Extension (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on the lever leg extension machine, adjusting the seat and backrest to a comfortable position.

2. Place your feet under the footpads with your toes pointing forward and your knees bent at a 90-degree angle.

3. Grasp the handles on the sides of the seat for stability and support.

4. Using your quadriceps muscles, straighten your legs by pushing against the footpads until your knees are almost fully extended but not locked.

5. Slowly lower the weight back down by bending your knees and returning to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions as per your workout plan.

Name: Lever Alternate Leg Extension (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on the lever alternate leg extension machine with your back against the seat and the padded roller resting on your thighs.

2. Place your feet on the footrests provided and grip the handles on the sides of the machine for support.

3. Ensure that your upper body remains stationary throughout the exercise, and engage your core muscles to stabilize yourself.

4. Slowly extend one leg forward by straightening your knee while exhaling. Keep your foot flexed throughout the movement.

5. Pause for a brief moment when your leg is fully extended, feeling the tension in your quadriceps (front thigh muscles).

6. Slowly return your leg back to the starting position while inhaling, and then repeat the same movement with the opposite leg.

Remember to maintain a controlled and smooth motion, avoiding any jerking or momentum. This exercise primarily targets your quadriceps, and it is important to focus on proper form to avoid injury and maximize the effectiveness of the workout. Make sure to consult with a fitness professional or trainer if you are unsure about the correct execution of this exercise.

Name: Lever Squat (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Position yourself correctly: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your toes pointed slightly outward. Place the barbell across your upper back and shoulders, resting it on your trapezius muscles.

2. Engage your core: Take a deep breath in and brace your core by pulling your belly button in towards your spine. This will help stabilize your spine throughout the movement.

3. Begin the descent: Initiate the movement by pushing your hips back and bending your knees. Lower yourself into a squatting position, ensuring that your knees track in line with your toes.

4. Reach proper depth: Continue descending until your thighs are parallel to the floor or slightly below. Maintain a straight back and avoid rounding your shoulders during this phase.

5. Ascend from the squat: Drive through your heels and extend your hips and knees simultaneously. Push the floor away from you and rise back up to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise: Complete the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout each squat.

Name: Lever Lateral Raise (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent.

2. Hold a plate loaded lever raise machine with both hands, gripping the handles firmly.

3. Keep your core engaged and your back straight as you lift the machine up and away from your body, lifting your arms out to the sides.

4. Continue to lift until your arms are parallel to the floor, or until you feel a stretch in your shoulder muscles.

5. Hold this position for a brief moment, then slowly lower the machine back to the starting position, controlling the movement.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control throughout.

Name: Sled Full Hack Squat
Description:
1. Load the sled with an appropriate amount of weight to challenge your leg muscles.

2. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, facing the sled. Position yourself so that your shoulders and upper back are against the padded support of the sled.

3. Grip the handles of the sled firmly with an overhand grip, keeping your elbows bent and your arms parallel to the floor.

4. Slowly lower your body by bending at the knees and hips, while keeping your back straight and your chest up. Lower until your thighs are parallel to the ground or as low as your flexibility allows.

5. Push through your legs and return to the starting position by extending your knees while keeping your core engaged. Avoid locking out your knees at the top of the movement.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Remember to consult with a certified fitness professional before attempting any new exercise, and always listen to your body to prevent injury.

Name: Hip Thrusts
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on the ground with your back against a sturdy bench or box and your knees bent at a 90-degree angle. Place a padded barbell or a heavy resistance band across your upper thighs.

2. Plant your feet firmly on the ground, hip-width apart, with your toes pointed slightly outward. Keep your arms relaxed on the sides.

3. Engage your core and squeeze your glutes as you lift your hips off the ground, pressing through your heels. Your upper body should be in a straight line from your knees to your shoulders.

4. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, making sure to fully contract your glutes, and then slowly lower your hips back to the starting position.

5. Repeat the exercise for the recommended number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement.

Name: Dumbbell Arnold Press
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on a bench or chair with your back straight and feet flat on the ground.

2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing towards your body and your elbows bent at a 90-degree angle, creating a starting position similar to the traditional dumbbell shoulder press.

3. Inhale as you slowly raise the dumbbells towards your shoulders, rotating your forearms so that your palms face forward at the top of the movement.

4. Exhale as you press the dumbbells upwards, extending your arms straight while keeping your palms facing forward.

5. Once at the top, inhale as you slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position by reversing the movement, rotating your forearms back to the original position with your palms facing towards your body.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining control and proper form throughout the entire motion.

Note: This description assumes that the user is familiar with basic dumbbell exercises and their form. It is always recommended to consult a professional trainer or exercise specialist before attempting any new exercises to ensure correct technique and avoid injury.

Name: Stationary Bike Run (version 3)
Description:
1. Sit on the stationary bike and adjust the seat height and distance from the handlebars to ensure a comfortable position.

2. Begin pedaling at a moderate pace to warm up your muscles.

3. Increase the resistance on the bike to a challenging level that will make you work harder.

4. Stand up on the pedals and continue pedaling while maintaining a good posture and engaging your core.

5. Alternate between sitting and standing every 30 seconds to 1 minute, keeping a consistent pedaling rhythm.

6. Focus on pushing through your legs and using your glutes to generate power during the standing intervals.

7. Continue this alternating pattern for the specified duration or until you reach your desired workout intensity.

8. Slow down your pedaling gradually as you near the end of the exercise to cool down your body.

Name: Cable Seated Chest Press
Description:
1. Sit down on the seated chest press machine and adjust the seat height and backrest to a comfortable position.

2. Grasp the handles of the cable machine, keeping your elbows bent and close to your sides.

3. Push the handles forward, extending your arms fully while exhaling. Keep your back and feet firmly positioned on the machine.

4. Pause for a moment at the end position, feeling the contraction in your chest muscles.

5. Slowly release the tension by pulling the cables back towards your body, bending your elbows and inhaling.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring your form and technique are maintained throughout the exercise.

Name: EZ Barbell Decline Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet securely placed at the end of the bench, ensuring a stable position.

2. Hold an EZ barbell with an overhand grip, making sure that your hands are shoulder-width apart.

3. Extend your arms fully and lift the barbell over your chest, keeping your elbows slightly bent throughout the movement.

4. Keeping your upper arms stationary, slowly lower the barbell towards your forehead by bending your elbows, ensuring that only your forearms are moving.

5. Pause briefly when the barbell is close to your forehead, and then slowly extend your elbows to raise the barbell back to the starting position.

6. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, making sure to maintain proper form and control throughout the exercise.

Name: Barbell Reverse Close-grip Bench Press
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Lie down on a bench with your feet flat on the ground and your back pressed against the bench.

2. Grasp the barbell with a reverse close-grip, around shoulder-width apart, using an overhand grip.

3. Lift the barbell off the rack and hold it directly above your chest, with your arms fully extended.

4. Slowly lower the barbell towards your chest, while keeping your elbows close to your body and your shoulder blades squeezed together.

5. Pause for a brief moment when the barbell touches your chest, then exhale and push the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form throughout the entire movement.

Name: Dumbbell Seated Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Sit on a bench with your back straight and hold a dumbbell in both hands, with your palms facing upward.

2. Begin by lifting the dumbbell overhead until your arms are fully extended.

3. Keeping your upper arms stationary, slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows.

4. Make sure to keep your elbows close to your head and engage your triceps muscles throughout the movement.

5. Once you feel a stretch in your triceps, pause for a moment, and then return to the starting position by straightening your arms.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout.

Name: Dumbbells Seated Triceps Extension
Description:
1. Sit on a flat bench with your back straight and your feet flat on the ground.

2. Hold a dumbbell (weighing whatever you're comfortable with) in each hand, keeping your palms facing inwards and your arms extended straight up. This is your starting position.

3. Slowly lower the dumbbells by bending your elbows until they are just above your shoulders. Keep your upper arms stationary and close to your head throughout the movement.

4. Once you have reached the bottom position, pause for a brief moment, then raise the dumbbells back up to the starting position by extending your arms.

5. As you extend your arms, avoid locking your elbows and maintain control of the weights. Remember to breathe out during this phase of the exercise.

6. Repeat the movement for your desired number of repetitions, ensuring a smooth and controlled motion throughout.

Name: Lever Seated Leg Press
Description:
1. Start by sitting on the leg press machine with your back resting against the padded backrest.

2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart on the footplate, ensuring that your knees are aligned with your toes and pointing in the same direction.

3. Engage your core muscles by bracing your abdomen and lower back.

4. Slowly push the footplate away from your body by straightening your legs, while maintaining the alignment of your knees and toes.

5. Pause for a moment at the fully extended position, then return to the starting position by bending your knees and lowering the footplate back towards your body.

Remember to adjust the weight on the machine according to your fitness level and gradually increase it as you get stronger. Additionally, ensure that you are using proper form throughout the exercise to avoid any injuries and maximize the benefits.

Name: Lever Lying Crunch
Description:
1. Lie flat on your back on a mat or a comfortable surface.

2. Extend your legs straight out in front of you.

3. Bend your elbows and place your hands behind your head, with your fingers lightly supporting your neck.

4. Engage your core muscles by gently lifting your shoulder blades off the ground, while keeping your lower back in contact with the mat.

5. Slowly lower your upper back and shoulder blades back down to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Remember to perform each repetition with proper form and control to maximize the effectiveness of the exercise. If you have any discomfort or pain, please stop and consult with a professional trainer or medical expert.

Name: Lever Chest Press (VERSION 4)
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on the lever chest press machine, ensuring your back is straight and firmly planted on the backrest.

2. Place your feet firmly on the ground and grasp the handles of the machine with an overhand grip.

3. Take a deep breath and slowly exhale as you extend your arms in front of you, pushing the handles away from your body.

4. Pause for a moment when your arms are fully extended, feeling a stretch in your chest muscles.

5. Inhale as you slowly bend your elbows and bring the handles back towards your chest, maintaining control throughout the movement.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and engaging your chest muscles throughout each rep.

Name: Lever Decline Chest Press (VERSION 2)
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by adjusting the seat height and backrest of the machine to a comfortable position.

2. Sit on the machine with your back against the backrest and grab the handles with an overhand grip.

3. Place your feet flat on the foot platform and firmly push against it to stabilize your body.

4. Begin the exercise by extending your arms straight in front of you, keeping a slight bend in your elbows.

5. Slowly lower the handles towards your chest, bending your elbows and engaging your chest muscles.

6. Pause for a moment and then press the handles back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms without locking your elbows.

7. Repeat the movement for the desired number of reps.

Remember to maintain proper form throughout the exercise by keeping your back against the backrest and avoiding excessive arching or swinging of the body. Make sure to breathe steadily and take breaks as needed.

Name: Lever Neck Extension (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Begin by sitting on the lever neck extension machine with your back resting against the padded support and your feet flat on the ground.

2. Adjust the seat height and position the lever arm so that it aligns with the back of your neck.

3. Grasp the handles on both sides of the machine, ensuring a secure grip.

4. Keeping your head aligned with your spine, slowly push the lever arm upward by extending your neck. Exhale during this movement.

5. Pause for a moment at the top of the movement, making sure to contract your neck muscles.

6. Slowly lower the lever arm back to the starting position, inhaling as you do so.

Remember to consult a fitness professional or instructor before attempting any new exercises, especially if you are unfamiliar with proper form and technique.

Name: Lever Neck Left Side Flexion (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Start by sitting on the plate-loaded lever neck machine with your back firmly against the backrest.

2. Adjust the lever arm so that the padded armrest is positioned at the left side of your neck.

3. Grasp the handles firmly with both hands and keep your feet flat on the ground.

4. Slowly lean your head towards your left shoulder, feeling a stretch along the right side of your neck.

5. Hold the stretch for a few seconds and then return to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise for the recommended number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout.

Name: Lever Neck Right Side Flexion (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Sit upright on the plate loaded lever machine, with your back against the pad and your feet flat on the ground.

2. Adjust the lever arm to a comfortable height, making sure it is aligned with the right side of your neck.

3. Grasp the handle of the lever arm with your right hand, keeping your elbow slightly bent.

4. Slowly lower your head towards your right shoulder, allowing the lever arm to apply gentle resistance.

5. Hold this stretched position for a few seconds, feeling a stretch on the left side of your neck.

6. Return to the starting position by slowly raising your head back to an upright position, with the lever arm supporting this movement.

7. Repeat the exercise for the recommended number of repetitions, focusing on a controlled and smooth motion.

Name: Lever Pullover (plate loaded)
Synergist: Deltoid Posterior, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. First, sit on the machine and place your feet flat on the floor.

2. Grasp the handles with an overhand grip and bring them towards your shoulders.

3. Keep your back straight and engage your core muscles.

4. Slowly lower the handles towards the rear of your head, maintaining control throughout the movement.

5. Pause briefly in the stretched position, feeling the stretch in your chest and shoulders.

6. Return the handles back to the starting position by contracting your chest muscles.

7. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

8. Ensure that you maintain proper form throughout the exercise, focusing on your breathing and using a controlled motion.

Remember to consult a fitness professional or trainer to ensure correct form and appropriate weight selection for this exercise.

Name: Lever Hip Extension (VERSION 2)
Description:
1. Start by lying face down on the ground with your legs fully extended and your arms resting alongside your body.

2. Bend your left knee at a 90-degree angle and position your left foot flat on the ground while keeping your right leg straight.

3. Engage your glutes and lower back muscles as you lift your right leg off the ground, aiming to bring it in line with your hips.

4. Hold the raised position for a brief moment, focusing on squeezing your glutes to maximize the contraction.

5. Slowly lower your right leg back down to the starting position, maintaining control and stability throughout the movement.

6. Repeat the exercise with your right leg, following the same steps.

Name: Lever Gripper Hands (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Begin by positioning yourself in front of a lever gripper machine.

2. Adjust the height of the machine's platform to a comfortable position for your range of motion.

3. Place your hands on the lever gripper handles, ensuring a firm grip with your palms facing each other.

4. Slowly squeeze the handles together, using your hand and forearm muscles, while keeping your upper arms stationary.

5. Hold the maximum contraction for a couple of seconds, feeling the tension in your hands and forearms.

6. Gradually release the pressure and allow the handles to move back to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Name: Lever Calf Press (plate loaded)
Description:
1. Begin by adjusting the seat height and load the desired amount of weight plates onto the machine.

2. Place your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart on the footplate, making sure that your toes are pointed forward and your heels are hanging off the edge.

3. Keeping your core engaged, push the footplate downwards by extending your ankles and driving your heels into the footplate. This will raise the loaded weight.

4. Continue pushing until your calves are fully contracted, and pause for a brief moment to feel the tension in your calf muscles.

5. Slowly return to the starting position by flexing your ankles and allowing the footplate to move upwards, while maintaining control over the weight plates.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps, focusing on maintaining proper form and controlled movements throughout the entire range of motion.

Remember to adjust the machine according to your comfort level and always consult a fitness professional if you are unsure about performing the exercise correctly.

Name: Dumbbell Rear Delt Raise
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Lateral, Levator Scapulae, Trapezius Upper Fibers, Wrist Flexors
Description:
1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing inwards towards your body.

2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge forward at the hips, maintaining a straight back. Keep your arms extended towards the floor, with a slight bend in your elbows. This is your starting position.

3. Engage your shoulder blades by retracting them, and lift both dumbbells out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground. Exhale as you perform this movement.

4. Hold the position for a brief pause at the top while squeezing your shoulder blades together to engage your rear delts.

5. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position, inhaling as you do so.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Inverted Row Bent Knees
Target: Infraspinatus, Latissimus Dorsi, Teres Major, Teres Minor , Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Posterior, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Find a sturdy horizontal bar or equipment at waist level that allows you to hang freely.

2. Position yourself facing the bar, with your feet together flat on the ground and your arms fully extended, gripping the bar at shoulder-width apart.

3. Bend your knees and keep your feet flat on the ground, creating a 90-degree angle with your legs.

4. Engage your core and retract your shoulder blades, pulling yourself up towards the bar. Keep pulling until your chest is in line with the bar and your elbows are fully bent, while maintaining a straight line from your head to your knees.

5. Pause for a brief moment in this top position, then slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position, ensuring controlled movement throughout.

Remember to maintain proper form, engage your core, and breathe steadily throughout the exercise.

Name: Lever Rotary Calf
Description:
1. Start by sitting on the lever rotary calf machine with your knees bent at a 90-degree angle and the balls of your feet resting on the platform.

2. Grip the handles provided on the machine to stabilize yourself.

3. Keeping your upper body stationary, slowly push downwards with your calves to raise the padded platform. Fully extend your ankles and feel the contraction in your calf muscles.

4. Hold the raised position for a second, then slowly lower the platform back down to the starting position, allowing your calves to stretch.

5. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining a controlled and steady pace throughout.

Note: Remember to adjust the weight or resistance on the machine according to your fitness level and gradually increase it as you progress.

Name: Dumbbell Seated Bent Arm Lateral raise
Synergist: Deltoid Anterior, Serratus Anterior, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand and place your feet flat on the floor.

2. Position your arms in front of your thighs with palms facing inward.

3. Bend your elbows slightly while keeping them close to your body.

4. Slowly raise your arms out to the sides, maintaining a slight bend in your elbows, until they reach shoulder level.

5. Pause for a moment when your arms are at the top and then slowly lower them back to the starting position.

Remember to start with a weight that is comfortable for you and gradually increase the weight as you build strength. Focus on maintaining proper form throughout the exercise to maximize the benefits.

Name: Lever Shoulder Press (plate loaded) (version 3)
Synergist: Deltoid Lateral, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Serratus Anterior, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Sit on the lever shoulder press machine with your back straight and feet planted firmly on the ground.

2. Adjust the seat so that the handles of the machine are slightly below shoulder level.

3. Grasp the handles with an overhand grip, keeping your elbows at a 90-degree angle and your palms facing forward.

4. Exhale as you push the handles up, extending your arms fully without locking your elbows.

5. Inhale as you slowly lower the handles back down to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Dumbbell Standing Inner Biceps Curl (version 2)
Description:
1. Stand up straight with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing inward towards your torso.

2. Keep your upper arms close to your body and allow your elbows to extend fully.

3. While keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the weights towards your shoulder by contracting your biceps.

4. Continue to curl the weights until your biceps are fully contracted, squeezing them at the top of the movement.

5. Inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Name: Spine Twist
Description:
1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended straight out in front of you.

2. Bend your right knee and place your right foot on the ground, keeping your left leg extended.

3. Place your right hand on the ground behind you for support, and extend your left arm out to the side at shoulder height.

4. Inhale deeply and as you exhale, twist your upper body to the right, bringing your left arm across your body and reaching for your right foot.

5. Hold the twisted position for a few seconds while maintaining a straight posture. Stretch and feel the twist in your spine.

6. Inhale as you release the twist and come back to the starting position. Repeat the exercise on the opposite side, bending your left knee and twisting your upper body to the left.

Name: Cable Lat Pulldown Full Range Of Motion
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Brachialis, Deltoid Posterior, Infraspinatus, Teres Major, Teres Minor, Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Adjust the cable machine: Ensure that the weight stack is appropriate for your fitness level and securely attach a wide-grip lat pulldown bar. Sit comfortably on the seat and place your knees under the pads.

2. Grasp the bar: Reach up and grab the bar with a wide overhand grip, ensuring that your hands are slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Make sure to fully extend your arms, keeping a slight bend in your elbows.

3. Position your torso: Sit straight with a slight lean back, maintaining a neutral spine. Keep your chest lifted and your core engaged throughout the exercise. Avoid slumping or arching your back excessively.

4. Initiate the movement: Begin by protracting your shoulder blades forward and then pull the bar towards your upper chest. As you pull down, focus on engaging your latissimus dorsi muscles while keeping your elbows pointed towards the floor. As you near the end of the movement, squeeze your shoulder blades together to fully contract your lats.

5. Reverse the movement: Slowly reverse the motion by allowing the bar to return to the starting position. Make sure to control the weight throughout the descent to avoid any jerking or swinging motions.

6. Perform the desired number of repetitions: Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions, maintaining proper form and control. Remember to exhale as you pull the bar down and inhale as you return to the starting position.

Note: It is crucial to always warm up properly before attempting any exercise and consult with a fitness professional to ensure that you are using the correct form and technique.

Name: Lever Seated Calf Press
Description:
1. Sit on the machine and place your feet on the platform with the balls of your feet resting comfortably.

2. Adjust the seat height so that your knees are slightly bent and your legs are at a 90-degree angle.

3. Grasp the handles on either side of the seat for support and stability.

4. Push the platform forward by extending your ankles, straightening your legs, and raising your heels as high as possible.

5. Hold the top position briefly, then slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps, maintaining a controlled and smooth motion throughout.

Name: Wide-Grip Chest Dip on High Parallel Bars
Target: Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head
Description:
1. Begin by standing between two high parallel bars, ensuring that they are stable and securely positioned.

2. Place your hands on the bars, gripping them firmly with your palms facing forward and your arms fully extended.

3. Step forward slightly, allowing your body to lean forward while maintaining a straight posture from head to toe.

4. Slowly lower your body by bending your elbows, while keeping your upper body leaned forward. Continue descending until your upper arms are parallel to the ground or slightly below.

5. Once you reach the bottom position, pause briefly and then exhale as you push yourself back up to the starting position by extending your elbows. Focus on using your chest muscles to perform the movement and avoid using excessive momentum or swinging.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, keeping control of the movement throughout and paying attention to proper form and technique.

Name: Split Squats
Description:
1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart.

2. Take a step forward with your right foot, ensuring your right knee is directly above your ankle.

3. Lower your body by bending both knees, aiming to bring your left knee towards the floor, while keeping your right knee at a 90-degree angle.

4. Push through your right heel to return to the starting position, maintaining control and balance.

5. Repeat the same steps with your left leg.

Name: Cable Seated Twist
Description:
1. Sit on a bench or chair facing the cable machine with your feet firmly planted on the ground.

2. Grasp the handle of the cable machine with both hands and extend your arms straight out in front of you.

3. Engage your core muscles and maintain an upright position throughout the exercise.

4. Slowly rotate your torso away from the cable machine using your obliques, keeping your hips facing forward.

5. Continue the twisting motion until you feel a stretch in your core, then slowly return to the starting position.

6. Repeat the movement on the opposite side, twisting in the opposite direction.

Remember to start with a light weight and gradually increase as you become more comfortable and confident with the exercise. Keep your movements controlled and avoid using momentum to maximize the effectiveness of the Cable Seated Twist.

Name: Inverse Leg Curl (on pull-up cable machine)
Synergist: Biceps Brachii, Deltoid Anterior, Gastrocnemius, Pectoralis Major Clavicular Head, Pectoralis Major Sternal Head, Popliteus, Sartorius, Triceps Brachii
Description:
1. Start by adjusting the cable pulley to the lowest position on the pull-up cable machine.

2. Lie flat on your stomach facing the cable machine and place your ankles in the foot straps attached to the cable.

3. Grab hold of the handles near your head and use your forearms and elbows to stabilize yourself.

4. Keeping your body in a straight line, engage your glutes and hamstrings to slowly lift both of your legs upward towards the ceiling.

5. Pause for a second at the top, squeezing your glutes and hamstrings, then slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position.

6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Note: It is crucial to maintain proper form throughout the exercise, focusing on the contraction of your glutes and hamstrings to avoid any strain or injury.

Name: Weighted Lying Neck Extension (with head harness)
Description:
1. Begin by lying face down on a flat bench or exercise mat, ensuring your head is hanging slightly off the edge.

2. Secure a head harness around your head, making sure it fits snugly but comfortably.

3. Place a weight plate or dumbbell onto the back of your head, using your hands to hold it securely in place.

4. Slowly lower your head towards the ground, maintaining control and keeping your neck muscles engaged.

5. Once you feel a stretch in your neck, slowly raise your head back up to the starting position, focusing on using your neck muscles to lift the weight.

6. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of reps, making sure to maintain proper form and control throughout each movement.

Remember to start with a light weight that you can handle safely and gradually increase the weight as your strength and comfort level improve.

Name: Weighted Lying Neck Flexion (with head harness)
Description:
1. Begin by lying flat on your back on a comfortable exercise mat or bench.

2. Secure a head harness around the crown of your head, making sure it fits snugly but not uncomfortably.

3. Attach a weight plate or any other desired weight to the head harness, ensuring it is securely fastened.

4. Slowly and controlled, lower your head down towards your chest, flexing your neck muscles, while keeping your upper body relaxed and stationary.

5. Hold the flexed position for a brief pause to fully engage your neck muscles.

6. Return to the starting position by slowly and controlled lifting your head back up to the neutral position with your neck straight.

Note: Do not rush through the exercise and make sure to maintain proper form to avoid any strain or injury.

Name: Weighted Standing Neck Extension (with head harness)
Description:
1. Secure the head harness firmly around your head, making sure it fits comfortably.

2. Attach the desired weight to the head harness using a weight plate or dumbbell, making sure it is securely fastened.

3. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your back straight.

4. Gently lower your chin towards your chest, keeping your neck and spine aligned.

5. Using your neck muscles, slowly lift your head upward, extending your neck as far as comfortably possible.

6. Hold the extended position for a second or two, then slowly lower your head back down to the starting position.

7. Repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on controlled movements and maintaining proper form throughout.

Name: Cable Seated Neck Extension (with head harness)
Description:
1. Sit on a sturdy exercise bench with your back straight and your feet firmly planted on the ground.

2. Attach a head harness to a cable machine, making sure it is secure and positioned at the top of the machine.

3. Place the harness around your head, making sure it rests comfortably on your forehead with the cable running over the top of your head.

4. Grasp the handles of the cable machine and ensure there is tension on the cable.

5. Slowly begin to extend your neck forward by moving your head away from the cable machine, using the resistance from the cable to provide a controlled movement.

6. Continue to extend your neck forward until you feel a slight stretch in the muscles at the back of your neck.

7. Hold this position for a brief moment, then slowly return to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

8. Repeat the exercise for the prescribed number of repetitions, focusing on the quality of each repetition rather than speed.

Name: Cable Seated Neck Flexion (with head harness)
Description:
1. Sit upright on a cable machine bench or chair with your back straight and your feet flat on the ground.

2. Attach a head harness to the cable machine, making sure it is secure and adjusted to fit snugly around your head.

3. Grasp the cable handles with both hands and position them at the sides of your head, holding onto the handles to stabilize the weight.

4. Start by relaxing your neck and allowing it to gently lean forward, feeling a stretch in the muscles at the back of your neck.

5. Slowly bring your head and neck back to the original position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

6. Repeat the motion for the desired number of repetitions, focusing on a controlled and smooth movement throughout.

Remember to consult with a fitness professional before attempting any new exercise, especially if you have any pre-existing medical conditions or concerns.

Name: Barbell Standing Concentration Curl
Description:
1. Stand straight with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip a barbell with an underhand grip.

2. Rest your upper arm against the inside of your thigh, ensuring that your elbow is fully extended and your arm is fully extended downwards.

3. Keeping the upper arm stationary, curl the barbell upward towards your shoulder by flexing your bicep. Exhale as you do this.

4. Continue the curl until the barbell is at shoulder level, then hold for a brief pause, squeezing your bicep.

5. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position, allowing your arm to fully extend. Inhale during this phase.

6. Repeat the curl with your other arm, alternating between arms for your desired number of reps.

Name: Cable Standing Face Pull (with rope)
Synergist: Brachialis, Brachioradialis, Deltoid Lateral, Infraspinatus, Teres Minor,Trapezius Lower Fibers, Trapezius Middle Fibers
Description:
1. Begin by attaching a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine.

2. Stand facing the cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent.

3. Grasp the rope handle with an overhand grip, palms facing down, and extend your arms straight in front of you, slightly below shoulder level.

4. While keeping your core engaged and maintaining a neutral spine, pull the rope towards your face by retracting your shoulder blades and squeezing your upper back muscles.

5. Once the rope reaches your face, pause for a brief moment, then slowly reverse the movement, extending your arms back to the starting position.
